The lotus root salad is also a MUST get!  Since it comes with a fish oil based sauce, it basically reminds me of vietnamese vermicelli, but without the noodle, meats, or chicken.  Great fried onion taste, and it's super healthy with all those root veggies.

Their 5 spice chicken is always veery tender and has a great flavor (I also very much like the fish sauce it comes with).

Their shaken beef is okay.  It's not bad, but I was expecting something more tender.

Lastly, for dessert, we tried the mango sticky rice.  The waiter really undersold this one, so I had my expectations low.  I've personally never had real mango sticky rice, and my friend said that is better.  But from somebody who's never tried it, I thought this fusion version was actually very tasty and interesting.

Overall, a little bit on the fancy side, so their apps and desserts, please expect small.  But their entrees are very generous proportions, and everything is very well-presented.

The overall flavor for every savory item is definitely citrus-- you'll find it in the sauces often.  Even their water is infused with orange and lemon.

excerpts: My favorite appetizers are the Lotus Root Salad and the Soft Shell Crab.
lotus root salad.author: Jay L.
lotus root salad.review:
High end Vietnamese fusion food. Don't expect the general Pho and Pork Chop run of the mill Vietnamese food.

The food is of the highest quality. My favorite appetizers are the Lotus Root Salad and the Soft Shell Crab. The Entree would be the Caramelized Sea Bass and the Curry Short Rib. Fried banana is the best dessert.

excerpts:
Taste just like Dragon Fly's, but missing the crunchy stuff

Lotus Root Salad

Shaken Beef

Seabass with brussel sprouts
lotus root salad.author: Karen H.
lotus root salad.review:
I been coming here for over 10 years. This place has really updated their menu and remodeled nicely. 

Love the food here. 

Beef Carpaccio with shrimp chips

Shrimp rice krispies-basically shrimp balls with rice that is fried on the outside

BBQ pork spring rolls-delish. Taste just like Dragon Fly's, but missing the crunchy stuff

Lotus Root Salad

Shaken Beef

Seabass with brussel sprouts

Garlic Noodle-wish it was the thicker  noodle. They use ramen noodles. 

Great food, good service, and affordable prices

excerpts: The shaking beef was to die for, and the lotus root salad was tantalizing.
lotus root salad.author: Suhl C.
lotus root salad.review: I returned to Le Soleil after a long absence.  Prior to the remodel, the food had gone downhilll, and I stopped going.  But curiosity got the better of me so I returned last week for dinner and was pleasantly surprised that both the service and the food was very good.  The shaking beef was to die for, and the lotus root salad was tantalizing.  We also had the turmeric crepe and the curry veggies, both of which were excellent.  I will definitely go back for the garlic roasted dungeness crab, the garlic noodles and the caramelized sea bass.  Yummy!

excerpts: I recommend the rice krispies, lotus root salad, and the shaken beef... but honestly, you cant go wrong with anything on the menu (atleast i havent run into any spoilers yet).
lotus root salad.author: Sean T.
lotus root salad.review: Upscale Viet food done extremely well! Ive been here several times and not once have I been disappointed by the food or the service.  Always love coming here. I recommend the rice krispies, lotus root salad, and the shaken beef... but honestly, you cant go wrong with anything on the menu (atleast i havent run into any spoilers yet).

excerpts: The lotus root salad, the garlic noodles are phenomenal.
I would take off 1/2  a star for the creme caramel which is not bad but not quite right and definitely boring.
I don't know about the creme brûlée.
I will try that instead next time.
lotus root salad.author: Patale M.
lotus root salad.review: UNBELIEVABLE. Sunday evening. 7:45pm. Only one other party in the restaurant ! ? ! ? Meanwhile, there was a line down the street at Burma....The spring roll was very fresh and delicious, the turmeric crepe ( note to owners: I would change the name of the crepe )  with shrimp and chicken was the best I've ever had. Very crispy on the outside. The lotus root salad, the garlic noodles are phenomenal. I would take off 1/2  a star for the creme caramel which is not bad but not quite right and definitely boring. I don't know about the creme brûlée. I will try that instead next time.

excerpts: Spring rolls, Lotus Root Salad, Caramelized Bass,
5-Spice Chicken, Macadamia Lamb, Shaken Beef, and garlic noodles (not on the menu)--all with their own unique vibrant flavors.
Jordan was an excellent waiter, and the whole staff seemed like they wanted us to truly enjoy our meal.
Can't wait to go back!
lotus root salad.author: Marc E.
lotus root salad.review: Delicious! Reasonably priced. Made for a lovely evening. Spring rolls, Lotus Root Salad, Caramelized Bass, 5-Spice Chicken, Macadamia Lamb, Shaken Beef, and garlic noodles (not on the menu)--all with their own unique vibrant flavors. Jordan was an excellent waiter, and the whole staff seemed like they wanted us to truly enjoy our meal. Can't wait to go back!

excerpts: The lotus root salad was OK.
lotus root salad.author: David C.
lotus root salad.review:
I came here a couple nights ago with 10 other people as part of a Meetup event.

FOOD:
I had the vegetarian spring rolls and Shaken Beef.  The springs rolls were OK.  The beef was mediocre - every piece was tough at the center.  Two people had the garlic noodles and both said the dish was very salty.  I tried the green papaya salad and it was bland, very little taste of anything.  The lotus root salad was OK.

SERVICE:
Service was pretty bad.  They lost track of two orders, didn't clear the tables completely, had some delays, and had trouble getting the bill correct.  It was a bad combination of an inexperienced server and a large group.

The owner gave all of us a complimentary dessert - I think it was jasmine ice cream with fried bananas.  Not enough to make up for mediocre food and service.

DECOR/CLEANLINESS:
Restaurant was recently renovated and it has very nice minimalist look.  Bathroom was clean.

excerpts: We ordered the Imperial egg rolls, Lotus root salad, Shaken beef and garlic noodle.
The Lotus root salad is very good and unique.
Also, I really love their garlic noodle, not very greasy.
This is one of the hidden gem in the Richmond district.
lotus root salad.author: Christine S.
lotus root salad.review: This is my second time eating here. They have recently remodeled and updated their menu. We ordered the Imperial egg rolls, Lotus root salad, Shaken beef and garlic noodle.  The Lotus root salad is very good and unique. Also, I really love their garlic noodle, not very greasy. This is one of the hidden gem in the Richmond district.

excerpts: Green papaya shrimp salad (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=W3bk1ovEVEhuuM2mhAb6ig&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Refreshing and clean
, this was a perfect palate opener.
green papaya shrimp salad.author: Mike C.
green papaya shrimp salad.review:
The beauty of San Francisco is the variety of cuisines available in a 7 x 7 mile radius.  Not only merely by countries or nations, you can find various regional cooking styles whether north, south, east, or west.  With Vietnamese cuisine, the south and north areas specialize in different signature dishes.

My friends who hosted this meal picked this neighborhood gem for a recent weeknight supper.  Being my first time, I deferred to them in composing our meal.  The dining room was about half full as we were seated at a wall table on the left.  Our party of four fit comfortably here but, after our order was placed, the table seemed small given the food that was to come.

Here's what we shared family style:

Appetizers
1.  Green papaya shrimp salad (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=W3bk1ovEVEhuuM2mhAb6ig&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Refreshing and clean, this was a perfect palate opener.  Love the tangy and sweet fish sauce dressing.

2.  Imperial rolls (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=0mLUIvtX3JTJsH8VICstmg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Always appreciate chefs who stay true to the cuisine, using the proper wrapper (not Chinese spring roll) to make this.  Always a table favorite.

3.  Crispy calamari (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=E1hfdF_pLCiOBeOfVhyXoA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - A non conventional take on fried calamari as this is seasoned with Thai chili sauce and other herbs.  Nice flavor contrast to the first two apps.

Mains
4.  Curry short ribs (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=8k-5WXGICzItTzseiSE3Tg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Tender and boneless, these were easy to eat and paired well with either the garlic noodles or the claypot rice.  The sauce was rich but note overly so.

5.  Garlic roasted Dungeness crab, whole (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Hb0KDx8ghfUY8J5WzizUmw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Served with garlic noodles, this crab was a solid dish.  The flavors weren't particularly distinct but you can't beat eating fresh crab when in season.  Be ready to lick those fingers.

6.  Caramelized sea bass (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fl0s19_lcgnZksbPO0RhDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Not my favorite but another decent dish.  Don't get me wrong, the fish was fine and paired well with the broccoli but it didn't particularly wow me.

7.  Claypot rice (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=cTbzYy1pdlt9zGrHMaTM3A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - There is certainly no shortage of ingredients in this dish as shown in the picture.  Just wished the rice was a tad more crispy for that clay pot effect.

By the time we finished our meal, the dining room was just about full, seemingly with mostly neighborhood locals.  We asked our waiter to pack the leftovers and, after our gracious hosts paid the bill, tried to walk off dinner along Clement Street.

The food ranks four plus with an extra half star for the efficient service (rounding up to five).

excerpts:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw)

Green Papaya Shrimp salad - shrimp, green papaya, carrots, mint, tamarind sauce.
green papaya shrimp salad.author: Al L.
green papaya shrimp salad.review:
Le Soleil calls its cuisine New Vietnamese, a blend of Vietnamese and French styles. Its small, modern décor location on Clement St. is a perfect backdrop to showcase this Vietnamese fusion cuisine. 

The menu is not a multi-page listing, but one page with selections of appetizers, salads, soups and entrees.  After checking out the menu, we ordered:

Imperial Rolls - the rolls were lightly fried and consisted of pork, mushroom, carrots and served with vermicelli, shredded carrots and dichon and lettuce and mint with fish sauce on the side.  Wrap the roll in lettuce with the condiments and drizzle some fish sauce on it for a delicious appetizer. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw)

Green Papaya Shrimp salad - shrimp, green papaya, carrots, mint, tamarind sauce.  A refreshing salad that has hint of sweetness from the tamarind sauce.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#RJ1Y4cU5b90Yn8N1M_N5tg)

House Fried Rice - duck and pineapple stirred fried with scallions and garlic.   Tasty fried rice with the minced duck.  
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#w9aePtdybcTgWGXxePIenQ)

Curry Short Ribs - braised boneless short ribs in yellow curry with potatoes, carrots and lime leaf served with garlic bread.  This was my favorite dish.  The short ribs were probably lightly fried creating a nice light crust to it. The beef was so tender and tasty with the coconut milk curry sauce.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#hY4bqKQNh1odO2yQWZH02Q)

A nice place on Clement for tasty New Vietnamese cuisine in a nice modern décor with friendly service.

excerpts: Caramelized sea bass (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fl0s19_lcgnZksbPO0RhDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Not my favorite but another decent dish.
Don't get me wrong, the fish was fine and paired well with the broccoli
caramelized sea bass.author: Mike C.
caramelized sea bass.review:
The beauty of San Francisco is the variety of cuisines available in a 7 x 7 mile radius.  Not only merely by countries or nations, you can find various regional cooking styles whether north, south, east, or west.  With Vietnamese cuisine, the south and north areas specialize in different signature dishes.

My friends who hosted this meal picked this neighborhood gem for a recent weeknight supper.  Being my first time, I deferred to them in composing our meal.  The dining room was about half full as we were seated at a wall table on the left.  Our party of four fit comfortably here but, after our order was placed, the table seemed small given the food that was to come.

Here's what we shared family style:

Appetizers
1.  Green papaya shrimp salad (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=W3bk1ovEVEhuuM2mhAb6ig&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Refreshing and clean, this was a perfect palate opener.  Love the tangy and sweet fish sauce dressing.

2.  Imperial rolls (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=0mLUIvtX3JTJsH8VICstmg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Always appreciate chefs who stay true to the cuisine, using the proper wrapper (not Chinese spring roll) to make this.  Always a table favorite.

3.  Crispy calamari (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=E1hfdF_pLCiOBeOfVhyXoA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - A non conventional take on fried calamari as this is seasoned with Thai chili sauce and other herbs.  Nice flavor contrast to the first two apps.

Mains
4.  Curry short ribs (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=8k-5WXGICzItTzseiSE3Tg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Tender and boneless, these were easy to eat and paired well with either the garlic noodles or the claypot rice.  The sauce was rich but note overly so.

5.  Garlic roasted Dungeness crab, whole (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Hb0KDx8ghfUY8J5WzizUmw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Served with garlic noodles, this crab was a solid dish.  The flavors weren't particularly distinct but you can't beat eating fresh crab when in season.  Be ready to lick those fingers.

6.  Caramelized sea bass (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fl0s19_lcgnZksbPO0RhDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Not my favorite but another decent dish.  Don't get me wrong, the fish was fine and paired well with the broccoli but it didn't particularly wow me.

7.  Claypot rice (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=cTbzYy1pdlt9zGrHMaTM3A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - There is certainly no shortage of ingredients in this dish as shown in the picture.  Just wished the rice was a tad more crispy for that clay pot effect.

By the time we finished our meal, the dining room was just about full, seemingly with mostly neighborhood locals.  We asked our waiter to pack the leftovers and, after our gracious hosts paid the bill, tried to walk off dinner along Clement Street.

The food ranks four plus with an extra half star for the efficient service (rounding up to five).

excerpts: Caramelized Sea Bass (5):
As expected, light and melts in your mouth.
caramelized sea bass.author: Jeremy L.
caramelized sea bass.review:
The lobster was amazing!  

Had to special order it in advance cause they go out and purchase a 3 pound lobster just for you!  They said thats the only way chef likes to make it so its not on the menu.  It was amazing though!  Served on a bed of fried rice which was big enough to feed the table.  Everything else that we got on the menu was also amazing!

Lotus Root Salad (5): The appearance of this thing was interesting.  After the first bite though, flavors and textures just exploded!  Just a great combination with bits of beef to contrast the light, sweet, and tangy salad flavors.   

Caramelized Sea Bass (5): As expected, light and melts in your mouth.  Excellent!

Luc Lac Shaken Beef (5): Tender, juicy cubes of beef served with a sort of tangy sauce that contrasts the salty meat well. 

Fried Banana with Coconut Ice Cream (4): Lightly fried bananas with some smooth coconut ice cream.  Simple yet delicious.  

Young Coconut (5): I hesitated on this one.  Just thought it'd be a cut open coconut that you can drink the water from.  Did not expect how amazing this coconut water was!  It was sweeter than expected and had a very refreshing flavor to it.  The coconut meat was also super soft and sweet!  Almost like eating a healthy and natural almond jello.  I'd eat this every day if I could.  

Everything was pretty solid and amazing on this visit.  The food was on point.  The chef even came out and asked us if everything was good and up to our standards (probably cause we special ordered the lobster).  Overall, amazing experience.  Will likely return when we're in the area.  If nothing else than to get that lotus root salad and the young coconut.  Super good!

excerpts: His specialties on the menu includes Flambéed Quail, Caramelized Sea Bass, and Roasted Garlic Dungeness Crab.
They also have brown rice.
caramelized sea bass.author: Cherylynn N.
caramelized sea bass.review:
Vietnamese food use to be a weekly staple for me. You could find me at Loi's, PPQ Noodle House, or Pho Huynh Hiep (Kevin's Noodle House) getting a nice facial over a hot steaming bowl of pho, face shoveling into a combo rice plate or getting buzzed off Vietnamese iced coffee. 

With age, came my intolerance to MSG and caffeine along with a couple of crow's feet, aching knees, and bladder leakage that will soon be in need of Depends. Not to mention passing out in front of the TV even before the guest list opens up at most clubs. Ohhh if only I can be 21 again. 

Anyhow, back to food talk because who doesn't love taking about food? :)

These days, I rarely if ever eat Vietnamese food because of the MSG. Yes, I know it's a staple in Asian cuisine but my body can no longer tolerate it so it makes it difficult to enjoy most Asian cuisine and the wallet-friendly prices. 

A rarity, Le Soleil serves upscale MSG-FREE Vietnamese cuisine with French influences. If you're looking for pho, please go somewhere else. It's ridiculous to complain that Le Soleil only has one pho option; they're not Pho 99. However, if you're looking to tantalize your taste buds with unique Vietnamese cuisine made with top-notch ingredients then Le Soleil is the place for you. 

The menu is fairly limited at just 22 items for dinner but with you can make special requests ahead of time with Chef Dennis (24-48 hour in advance so he can buy the ingredients) who's a super nice guy. His specialties on the menu includes Flambéed Quail, Caramelized Sea Bass, and Roasted Garlic Dungeness Crab. They also have brown rice. Yay!

We started with the Beef Carpaccio ($8). Sorry, no pic for this app since my phone decided to not share this deliciousness with you and deleted the pic *shakes fist*. The tender slices of filet mignon was lightly dressed in a citrus, mint, and chili concoction and served alongside a basket of freshly fried thick shrimp chips (not that stale, flimsy cheap shit at Chinese restaurants). A real solid starter. 

The Bo Luc Lac: Shaking Beef ($16) came next; spelled "shaken" on the menu. We added an egg on request (+$2) and it came on a sizzling platter which reminded me of Filipino sisig: http://bit.ly/186ePRX. Just when I thought I tasted the best bo luc lac at Bodega Bistro in TL, a bite of the mouth-wateringly buttery bo luc lac made me realized the BEST has been hidden here at Le Soleil. Not a dish I wanted to share, I'll tell you that much. 

All heads turned when the gargantuan Garlic Roasted Crab w/ Egg Noodles ($32) was placed on our table for two: http://bit.ly/18TBgMz. Insanely fresh, the crab was delicately tender and ohh sooo sweet. The bits of garlic infused just enough garlickyness without leaving us with major dragon breath. The innards of the crab was then mixed with the egg noodles for an artery-clogging carb fest. My only gripe was the noodles; it was more mushy and I like my noodles al-dente with a toothsome chew. Perhaps a thicker noodle would have fared better? 

I know people want to know if Le Soleil's crab is as good as PPQ or Thanh Long and there's really no comparison as both PPQ and Thanh Long uses tons of MSG to flavor their signature crab dishes. As I've said, that's like comparing real tits to fake ones. Don't get me wrong, I like fake ones too and I would get a pair to fix my lopsided ones but there's really no comparison.

Because it's not a complete dinner without dessert (especially when dining out), we wanted to order the Tempura Ice Cream but one of the waitresses brought us the Trio of Ice Cream. When we told her we had ordered the Tempura Ice Cream she said they didn't have it. We instead requested the Fried Bananas with Ice Cream ($4.50) which was tempura battered bananas served with coconut ice cream (sorry, no pic). Huh? They had the tempura batter for the bananas but not for the ice cream? This made no sense. 

Aside from this minor blunder, service was very friendly and attentive. A smile goes a long way which most Asian restaurants don't seem to get. But Le Soleil does. All smiles here--thank you!

Along with the atypical Vietnamese fare and good service, Le Soleil has a very contemporary and more upscale ambiance which makes it great for dates. Beware of the terrible parking situation in this area though. 

Everything about Le Soleil seems to warrant almost 5 stars. So why just 4? I asked if Chef Dennis can replicate Brodard's FAMOUS Nem Nuong Cuon in SoCal: http://bit.ly/1g5JNyD and he says he can with advanced notice. Going to hold out on that one extra star until I can meet my beloved crack rolls without travelling 400+ miles. If he can deliver, I will gladly upgrade to 5 stars with a big smooch on the face! I hope he doesn't mind sloppy seconds! I'm kidding....

excerpts: For my dinner I got the Caramelized Sea Bass
and it was delicious.
It was a soy glazed sea bass with a side of brussel sprouts and rice.
The sea bass was packed with flavor without being fishy.
I would definitely not mind paying Le Soleil another visit
caramelized sea bass.author: Alysha F.
caramelized sea bass.review:
An interesting find in the City. Not your typical Vietnamese joint with mainly pho and vermicelli, Le Soleil actually deviates a lot from the traditional Vietnamese foods to more specialty items. 

There's a decent amount of street parking along the entire block which is convenient. The decor of the restaurant is classy without being uptight. We got the Shrimp Rice Krispies for appetizers which didn't have a whole lot of flavor and kinda had a weird texture but was cool to try. For my dinner I got the Caramelized Sea Bass and it was delicious. It was a soy glazed sea bass with a side of brussel sprouts and rice. The sea bass was packed with flavor without being fishy. I would definitely not mind paying Le Soleil another visit

excerpts: I enjoyed my first visit recently and was very impressed with the gracious service, 'casual/smart' decor, tasty dishes (nice use of spices), the caramelized sea bass with brussels sprouts was so exceptional I had difficulty sharing it with my friend!
caramelized sea bass.author: barbara b.
caramelized sea bass.review:
I love this wonderful place!  I enjoyed my first visit recently and was very impressed with the gracious service, 'casual/smart' decor, tasty dishes (nice use of spices), the caramelized sea bass with brussels sprouts was so exceptional I had difficulty sharing it with my friend!

I subscribe to the James Beard take on food:  "Good is good".  Le Soleil food and its preparation is wonderful.  Good wine list, too.

excerpts: Caramelized Sea Bass --
Perhaps my perfect dish of the night.
caramelized sea bass.author: Laura C.
caramelized sea bass.review:
I found this place purely by using Yelp and I hope my review convinces you to come too. Le Soleil is a Vietnamese-French fusion restaurant that manages to be classy but not snobby. It's located in a quiet neighborhood in Richmond and the interior atmosphere is quite relaxing and modern as well. 

We arrived around 5:30 or 5:45 and the restaurant was almost empty. More people started coming in after 6:30 but it never felt crowded or noisy. Our waiters were very attentive in refilling our glasses (lemon- and apple-infused water) and changing our plates. But the food was the best part:

Beef Carpaccio -- Appetizer of thinly sliced rare filet mignon. It was my first time having raw beef and the meat melted in my mouth like fresh sashimi. Yum. The side notes of mint, onion, and roasted garlic were satisfying as well.

Green Papaya Salad -- This might have tasted better if it wasn't served right after the Beef Carpaccio, since it had the same mint-onion taste. The green papaya is in shreds and reminded me of turnip salad. It wasn't bad, but I don't think I'd order it again when I return (because I will return).

Quail -- Mmmm. The quail is already cooked when it arrives, but the waiter torches it at the table for good measure and good show. The four of us shared one quail, which was sweet and tender to perfection.

Caramelized Sea Bass -- Perhaps my perfect dish of the night. The texture and taste couldn't have been more satisfying and the brussel sprouts underneath were some of the yummiest I've had.

Dungeness Crab and Garlic Noodles -- I'm not a big fan of garlic noodles but these were delectable. I especially loved the crab, which was drizzled over with the contents of the crab shell (I'm Chinese and my family loves eating that). 

Turmeric Crepe -- I'm not a big fan of the fried taste so this wasn't my favorite dish, but it was also carefully prepared with carrots and greens on the side.

Tofu Eggplant -- Yummy, good with rice (rice texture was great too), and pretty reminiscent of Chinese food in flavor. 

My overall impression of Le Soleil was that each and every detail is carefully attended to. Not only was the food delicately prepared, but the bathroom was very clean and elegantly decorated, and the bill came in a bamboo cup instead of the usual tray or leather book. The meal was a little pricey, at $24 per person, but maybe that's just because we kept ordering more to try the menu. We got what we paid for, though. I'm so glad we live close to San Francisco because we are coming back here for sure.

excerpts:
Favorites: Things you have to try 
Shrimp Rice Krispies
Chilean Caramelized Sea Bass with Brussel Sprouts 
and ask about the Fried Crab or Lobster.
You won't regret it.
caramelized sea bass.author: Lexie S.
caramelized sea bass.review:
I love coming to this place with my husband and friends.  I've never had a bad meal.  The food is great and so is the service.  We never make reservations and so far it's worked out for us.  

Favorites: Things you have to try 
Shrimp Rice Krispies
Chilean Caramelized Sea Bass with Brussel Sprouts 
and ask about the Fried Crab or Lobster.  You won't regret it.

excerpts: My caramelized sea bass was to die for, it was flaky and melted in my mouth.
My party of four also ordered 2 shaken beefs and the lamb chops, all of which are must tries.
All of their teas are so aromatic and fancy, I wanted to take the tea leaves to go.
Their fried banana, mango & coconut ice cream, and their sticky rice was superb.
I seriously felt like I had a satisfying, delicious meal.
I understand that their menu changes seasonally so there is always a reason to come back
and I will definitely be back to try their lunch!
caramelized sea bass.author: Kawai N.
caramelized sea bass.review: This place is amazing! Great customer service, I recommend their soft shell crab to start. My caramelized sea bass was to die for, it was flaky and melted in my mouth. My party of four also ordered 2 shaken beefs and the lamb chops, all of which are must tries. All of their teas are so aromatic and fancy, I wanted to take the tea leaves to go. Their fried banana, mango & coconut ice cream, and their sticky rice was superb. I seriously felt like I had a satisfying, delicious meal. I understand that their menu changes seasonally so there is always a reason to come back and I will definitely be back to try their lunch!

excerpts: We had flaming quail, beef carpaccio, crab with garlic noodle, bun rieu, caramelized sea bass, and a new beef stew dish recommended by the owner.
For dessert, we had fried banana, and this dessert is a killer, complete our evening of wonderful food.
Servers are very tentative, and well trained.
The executive chef came out & checked on customers...that shows the caring for customers.
We will definitely come back to Le Soleil whenever we are in town.
caramelized sea bass.author: Vinh D.
caramelized sea bass.review: We were in SF with our friends, and we were craving for Vietnamese food. We found Le Soleil via Yelp so we gave it a try. It turned out to be a perfect choice...love the decor, very intimate ambiance, and most of all, their food. We had flaming quail, beef carpaccio, crab with garlic noodle, bun rieu, caramelized sea bass, and a new beef stew dish recommended by the owner. For dessert, we had fried banana, and this dessert is a killer, complete our evening of wonderful food. Servers are very tentative, and well trained. The executive chef came out & checked on customers...that shows the caring for customers. We will definitely come back to Le Soleil whenever we are in town.

excerpts: The food was very tasty -- we got the caramelized sea bass (a-freaking-MAZING!) and the shaken beef (tasty but standard).
caramelized sea bass.author: Nami S.
caramelized sea bass.review:
It's funny, I've lived a few blocks from this place for the last 4 years but only just tried it for the first time last week. So many restaurants on Clement, so little stomach space.

Anyway. This place was pretty good, a nice ethnic respite from all the ethnic dives on the street. Not that I don't love my ethnic dives, but it's nice to not always have to have  ethnic food under fluorescent lights. The food was very tasty -- we got the caramelized sea bass (a-freaking-MAZING!) and the shaken beef (tasty but standard).

Next time, I might have to get the sea bass again, but will skip the shaken beef. The waitress said that the crab was sick-awesome, so will go for that. Had the mango sticky rice for dessert, not great not bad.

excerpts: I've previously had their caramelized sea bass, and that is also superb.
caramelized sea bass.author: Eileen W.
caramelized sea bass.review:
The food and hospitality at Le Soleil makes my trip from Mountain View to San Francisco worth it!  My best friend and I just had dinner there, and we were treated graciously by the staff, and had their imperial rolls as an appetizer followed by garlic roasted dungeness crab, and five spice chicken.  All were to die for.  The staff accommodated our request to shell the crab; it was stellar!  I've previously had their caramelized sea bass, and that is also superb.  

Le Soleil is a destination restaurant that's an asset to the Richmond neighborhood.  Can't wait till my next visit.

excerpts: I highly recommend the Caramelized Sea Bass.
It was just the right amount of crispy-ness to make it addicting.
The Beef Carpaccio was also a big hit for us.
caramelized sea bass.author: Erin W.
caramelized sea bass.review:
The first time my bf and I came here, it was a lot better than expected.  It has slowly worked its way into our "places where we return to go" category. 

We tend to order one meal to many between the two of us to try out different items on the menu, but this time we didn't have any left overs. 

I highly recommend the Caramelized Sea Bass.  It was just the right amount of crispy-ness to make it addicting.  The Beef Carpaccio was also a big hit for us.   I haven't had anything on the menu to complain about yet, and we keep coming back for more.  

Parking it tough, but a great place to walk to if you live close enough and the bus goes near.

excerpts: The Entree would be the Caramelized Sea Bass and the Curry Short Rib.
Fried banana is the best dessert.
caramelized sea bass.author: Jay L.
caramelized sea bass.review:
High end Vietnamese fusion food. Don't expect the general Pho and Pork Chop run of the mill Vietnamese food.

The food is of the highest quality. My favorite appetizers are the Lotus Root Salad and the Soft Shell Crab. The Entree would be the Caramelized Sea Bass and the Curry Short Rib. Fried banana is the best dessert.

excerpts: Caramelized Sea Bass was the star dish.
caramelized sea bass.author: Jorge C.
caramelized sea bass.review:
Incredible!!! If you live within 1 mile of this location - GO!!! Food is very very tasty!!

Skip the spring rolls, the only thing that wasn't good....at all. 

Caramelized Sea Bass was the star dish. Get it and you will love it. 

Portobello dish, Shaken Beef and the BBQ Pork were all amazing!!!

Service was ok. They had a small problem  with our order in the kitchen, but it was fine. I work in the industry and understand nothing is ever perfect. But the food is unbelievable!!!  Please support this local gem!

excerpts: My favorite dishes were the turmeric crepes to start, and the caramelized sea bass main dish was melt in your mouth delicious.
The ambiance wasn't especially romantic or intimate though, but it was a very nice place.
caramelized sea bass.author: Clare T.
caramelized sea bass.review: we had valentine's dinner here and it was lovely and not that expensive.  My favorite dishes were the turmeric crepes to start, and the caramelized sea bass main dish was melt in your mouth delicious.   The ambiance wasn't especially romantic or intimate though, but it was a very nice place.

excerpts: I will definitely go back for the garlic roasted dungeness crab, the garlic noodles and the caramelized sea bass.
Yummy!
caramelized sea bass.author: Suhl C.
caramelized sea bass.review: I returned to Le Soleil after a long absence.  Prior to the remodel, the food had gone downhilll, and I stopped going.  But curiosity got the better of me so I returned last week for dinner and was pleasantly surprised that both the service and the food was very good.  The shaking beef was to die for, and the lotus root salad was tantalizing.  We also had the turmeric crepe and the curry veggies, both of which were excellent.  I will definitely go back for the garlic roasted dungeness crab, the garlic noodles and the caramelized sea bass.  Yummy!

excerpts: We ordered the crepe, five spice chicken and the caramelized sea bass.
Everything was delicious including the rice.
I had the rose tea which smelled incredible.
Great, fast service as well.
Was very impressed.
Can't wait to return.
caramelized sea bass.author: E. N.
caramelized sea bass.review: LOVED this place! We ordered the crepe, five spice chicken and the caramelized sea bass. Everything was delicious including the rice. I had the rose tea which smelled incredible. Great, fast service as well. Was very impressed. Can't wait to return.

excerpts: Loved the Caramelized Sea Bass and had the Short Ribs too.
The service was very good and we went on a Saturday night.
The owner stopped by and talked to us for at least 15 minutes.
This is a good neighborhood find!
I'm going back again
that's for sure.
caramelized sea bass.author: Natalie W.
caramelized sea bass.review:
Wonderful food and great service!  We had a bunch of dishes including the fun Quail appetizer that get's "flamed" at your table. Very tasty, but of course not a lot of meat on those quail bones. 

Loved the Caramelized Sea Bass and had the Short Ribs too. The service was very good and we went on a Saturday night. The owner stopped by and talked to us for at least 15 minutes. This is a good neighborhood find!  I'm going back again that's for sure. ;-)

excerpts: Best things to order: shrimp chips ($2 during happy hour!), quail which is flambed tableside, the shaken beef, and the caramelized sea bass.
The sea bass had a delicious soy glazed crust which was perfect.
A lot of the lower ratings for this place came before it was remodeled and reopened.
The food was amazing!
caramelized sea bass.author: Lauren C.
caramelized sea bass.review: Best things to order: shrimp chips ($2 during happy hour!), quail which is flambed tableside, the shaken beef, and the caramelized sea bass. The sea bass had a delicious soy glazed crust which was perfect. A lot of the lower ratings for this place came before it was remodeled and reopened. The food was amazing!

excerpts: Thumbs up on oxtail soup, eggplant & tofu, and portobello mushroom.
The lamb chops weren't my favorite.
The shaken beef was tender.
portobello.author: Angelia H.
portobello.review:
Ambience is nice, service is good. Overall, I felt the appetizers were better tasting than the main dishes. 
The lotus root salad and green papaya salad were good, but tasted similar. I liked the duck rolls, calamari, beef carpaccio, and would have ordered seconds if we didn't have all the other dishes. Lollipop chicken and shrimp krispies were decent for deep fried food lovers. Garlic noodles and crab fried rice were just enough for side dishes. Thumbs up on oxtail soup, eggplant & tofu, and portobello mushroom. The lamb chops weren't my favorite. The shaken beef was tender.

excerpts: - Portobello Mushrooms with green beans and Brussels - I could had just eaten this dish alone with a bowl of rice and would had been content!
The portobello shrooms soaked up all the flavors of the sauce, it was tender beyond belief and could easily pass as a protein dish.
The green beans and Brussels were cooked with a slight crunchy texture and was so delicious to eat.
portobello.author: Jenny T.
portobello.review:
Le Soleil serves traditional Vietnamese cuisine in a quant modernized dining room.  All the wait staff wears black and are extremely friendly.  It's a perfect place to dine for a celebratory reason or for just because...

We booked easily online and was seated right away.  The tables are small and we could barely fit all the dishes served up for us for family style dining.  Or maybe we were just little piggies and should be ordering individual dishes instead.  But none the less, we are Asians, that's just how we roll. Banquet family style is more our to our upbringing.  Plus, we are piggies that wanna taste everything!!  

Each dish that came out was delightfully scumcious!  And here we goooo...

5 STARS - SUPER YUM
! - Lotus root beef salad - the lotus was crunchy with bits of marinated beef drizzled with a light tangy flavor
! - Beef carpaccio with shrimp chips - thinly sliced raw beef with a tangy lime sauce topped with a peppery chopped red onions with deep fried shallots.  You're supposed to eat this with the shrimp chip but I prefer to roll a beef up with onions and shallots, then pop it into my mouth.  It's a explosion of yummies in your mouth
! - Portobello Mushrooms with green beans and Brussels - I could had just eaten this dish alone with a bowl of rice and would had been content!  The portobello shrooms soaked up all the flavors of the sauce, it was tender beyond belief and could easily pass as a protein dish.  The green beans and Brussels were cooked with a slight crunchy texture and was so delicious to eat.  Yum!!

4 STARS - GOOD YUM
! - Shanking beef - this was marinated beef with a lemon pepper dipping sauce.  I wish the sauce had more pepper and lemon, it was a bit drowned out for me
! - Garlic crab with noodles - The crab meat was very fresh but it's not my favorite crab dish.  The noodles were good but again, I've had better.
! - Coconut lemon grass chicken soup - the broth was so good but I thought the chicken got in my way.  I love how there were pineapples found in the soup.

2.5 STARS - OKAY
! - BBQ pork spring rolls - it was okay, nothing special

We each had a glass of wine: Merlot, Sauvignon blanc, Pinot noir, Cabernet 

And the owner found out we were celebrating a birthday and he offered us a free dessert of flan with a lite candle.  That was so nice!

All this came out to $131+tip.  For a birthday celebration, this was a decent outcome, as we've spent wayyy more before.  And we were all content and extremely full!

NOTES:  no cocktail drinks available.  Dessert menu was kinda lame, they need to amp that part up.  Parking was not exactly easy.

excerpts: Portobello Mushroom: on the dinner menu and comes with three mushrooms and green beans in what tasted like an oyster sauce.
portobello.author: Lauren Y.
portobello.review:
Sweet place for a contemporary take on Vietnamese cuisine. We came for lunch but ordered from the dinner menu because the dishes were much better.

What to order:
Shaken beef: super tender beef cubes with softened onions

Beef carpaccio: came with yummy shrimp chips.. Was a smaller portion than usual and a bit too minty for my taste but overall good

Portobello Mushroom: on the dinner menu and comes with three mushrooms and green beans in what tasted like an oyster sauce. Tasty. 

Vietnamese ice coffee: standard faire.. If you haven't had it before, Viet coffee always comes with a nice kick and condensed milk ;)

What to think twice about:
Traditional pho - the broth was decent but could have used more of it in the bowl. Decent pho but I believe you can better elsewhere. Go for their more standout dishes! 


Service was nothing outstanding. Our server forgot our order of garlic noodles and seemed kind of grumpy. Really enjoyed the dinner entrees.

excerpts: Stir fried Portobello mushrooms with Brussels sprouts and string beans - excellent stir fry with a good wok sear.
Yet the theme of sugar is a touch strong here, although it provided the needed carmelization.
portobello.author: Ken K.
portobello.review:
Those of you who have lived in the SF Bay Area and through the 1980s/90s will no doubt remember the famous Thanh Long restaurant (which spun its high end counterpart Crustacean) along with a few copycats or competitors offering somewhat similar fare. I cannot speak for Vietnamese expats and how they view this sort of fare, but they have taken some traditional and not so traditional receipes, and figured out a way to make the best use of local/American ingredients and made it into their signature dish (garlic butter roasted Dungeness crab). It's easy to say on one hand that it's Vietnamese style moo shoo poo poo doo doo...but it's not cheap for one thing!

Chinese American MSPPDD is cheap, and frankly even PF Chang's is not expensive like MY China or Koi Palace in comparison. The bottom line is, does it taste good, and what kind of clientele does it attract? WTF, did I just abbreviate moo shoo poo poo doo doo MSPPDD like Xiao long bao (XLB)??

With Le Soleil, while the style and approach can be argued to be similar to that of Thanh Long, there is a bit of a Chinese influence in a good number of the dishes. And that is because of the executive chef Dennis Wong, who is Vietnamese Chinese and who also understands the target demographic.

This restaurant continues to be very popular for a number of reasons. The food might not be authentic Vietnamese or regional specific by any means, but attracts a stready stream of clientele, mostly locals who live in the area (of which a majority are Cantonese speaking Chinese folks). 

With that said this meal was overall enjoyable.

Café sua da - eeeek no bueno. Crustacean and Thanh Long had a much better iced Vietnamese coffee with condensed milk in relation. This one had this whacked up Vanilla latte caramelly like flavor, like a really bad pre-made Lee's Sandwiches (McBanh Mi or Banh Bucks) iced milk coffee.

Young coconut - this was dessert. For those too lazy or don't have the hardware at home to cut it open. Drink the juice then use your ice cream scooping skills to carve out the coconut meat (delish).

Pan fried combination noodle - To be fair even a horrible chain (from the South and East Bay) New Tung Kee had something like this, but obviously this is way better. Vietnamese Chinese approach to HK style pan fried noodles (jeen meen), except the noodles were arranged like a "cake" format, with thicker layers that elevated the toppings (the stir fried combo of broccoli, chicken, shrimp etc). The sauce was a tad too sweet for my liking but otherwise seasoned well. Guessing the sugar is a bit of a crucial component to draw in the masses and is a bit of an unfortunate theme of a number of stir fry dishes here. So instead of asking to "hold the MSG, less salt, less oil" with here it's probably best to ask for "less sugar" in the dishes (unless sauces are pre-seasoned).

Flambe quail - this is actually one of their signature specials. The quail arrives at the table with some sort of flammable alcohol on top, and the watistaff sets it on fire for a pyro show....but don't worry the bird is already marinated and dead so it's not like Rage Against the Machine's first album cover, but is absolutely rockin'. When the fire dies down the bird is at the right temperature to be consumed. The flambé seals in the juices. Now in terms of flavoring the quail has this remarkable cross between a sexcellent soy sauce chicken coupled with the complexity of Cantonese cha siu (bbq) marinade...maybe a tad Lee Kum Kee esque in flavoring. It was like deja vu eating this. $hit, no wonder there were quite a number of Chinese customers in here. Although a tad sweet (my only gripe), this was very tasty.   

Stir fried Portobello mushrooms with Brussels sprouts and string beans - excellent stir fry with a good wok sear. Yet the theme of sugar is a touch strong here, although it provided the needed carmelization. If they could execute this similar to the sambal string beans at Shiok Singaporean Kitchen (more savory and umami), this would work even better.

Roasted crab with garlic noodles - ended up getting half crab, since there was already a lot of food. But those of you who love to whip out the cameras to let them eat first (before others) will know that excess is best...so therefore a whole crab over noodles will look a lot better than a few severed limbs (crab limbs that is). The noodles were like curly ramen....almost but not quite to the thinness of instant noodle ramen packets, yet were still quite tasty. Crab was not in season of course so not as fatty or juicy, but enjoyable.

It is said that the son (Walter Kwok) of one of the founders of Hong Kong commercial real estate conglomerate (Sun Hung Kei properties) dined here, and loved the food so much he was instrumental in helping Dennis open up Le Soleil at Royal Garden Tsim Sa Tsui in HK. Who are you to argue with the tastebuds of a multi zillionaire? If only I had a sponsor like that to write paid food reviews in HK  :-D

excerpts: Portobello w/asparagus - tossed on a sweet soy sauce , these were a hit.
Being a vegetarian isn't half bad.
Came with white rice and of course ....
portobello.author: Sammy T.
portobello.review:
Wanted to try a new vietnamese fusion and this place came up. We stopped by for a Sunday dinner. Here's what we had:

Shrimp Krispy - fried grounded fillings with burnt rice for that nice crunchy bite. Came with a peanut sauce that overpowers the filling. Wanted to try it based on the description and it was ok. Think I'll try something else next time. 

Papaya salad - typical vietnamese salad. The fish sauce wasn't overpowering, so that was nice. Large portion too, so everyone had at least two servings. Crisp papaya and carrots along with fried onions. Just love he texture of this dish

Sea bass - delicious. Caramelized and the sea bass itself was cooked well. Definitely a good choice. Came with Brussels sprouts and rice. 

Macadamia encrusted Lamb shanks - not a particular fan of lamb in general, but the dish  was good. Came with Brussels sprouts. Again.

Portobello w/asparagus - tossed on a sweet soy sauce , these were a hit. Being a vegetarian isn't half bad. Came with white rice and of course ....Brussels sprouts. 

House fried rice - fried rice with dick and pineapple. Can't miss item and it was tasty. Lots of dishes came with rice so I'll pass next time. No Brussels sprouts with this dish. 

Many vietnamese fusion places out there and it's nice to have found another to add to the rotation. Service was friendly and they kept our water full every time in dipped below halfway. None of this matters unless the food is good so, that's the icing on the cake. I will be back.

excerpts: Portobello dish, Shaken Beef and the BBQ Pork were all amazing!!!
portobello.author: Jorge C.
portobello.review:
Incredible!!! If you live within 1 mile of this location - GO!!! Food is very very tasty!!

Skip the spring rolls, the only thing that wasn't good....at all. 

Caramelized Sea Bass was the star dish. Get it and you will love it. 

Portobello dish, Shaken Beef and the BBQ Pork were all amazing!!!

Service was ok. They had a small problem  with our order in the kitchen, but it was fine. I work in the industry and understand nothing is ever perfect. But the food is unbelievable!!!  Please support this local gem!

excerpts: For our entrees, we tried the Shaken Beef, Grilled Pork, and Portobello Mushroom.
All very good!
portobello.author: Zherr-Anne A.
portobello.review:
Having grown up in the Richmond district, I was surprised that I had never heard about this place until this week. Based off of the reviews here on Yelp, I decided it was worth giving it a try. 

Everything from the water to the entrees were delicious. I had dinner here with three other friends so we were able to try a variety of things.

Bbq Pork Spring Rolls-- we received for free from checking-in on Yelp. A lot tastier than I expected.
Garlic Noodles-- we really wanted to try this after seeing it in all the reviews, but it wasn't on the menu. If you ask your server about it, they can make it. A large order was enough for the four of us. 
Quail-- prepared tableside. It was a great presentation, and it was tasty!

For our entrees, we tried the Shaken Beef, Grilled Pork, and Portobello Mushroom. All very good! I recommend any of the three.

Service was great as well. Our server constantly checked up on us and refilled our waters (which was infused with a variety of fruits like lemons, apples, and oranges-- very refreshing!). 

All in all, another great restaurant on Clement St. Will definitely be coming back here to try the rest!

excerpts: There are also vegetarian options like the tofu eggplant and curry veggies.
But, gosh, the garlic-roasted Dungeness crab?
Absolutely delightful, whether the crab itself or the egg noodles that serve as the bed.
So deliciously garlicky.
tofu eggplant.author: Vincent L.
tofu eggplant.review:
Quality, authentic Vietnamese fare done in a slightly swankier, more polished setting than, say, hole-in-the-wall restaurants. That having been said, the prices are still quite reasonable.

Traditional dishes like the bo luc lac (shaken beef) and grilled pork are quite dependable. There are also vegetarian options like the tofu eggplant and curry veggies. But, gosh, the garlic-roasted Dungeness crab? Absolutely delightful, whether the crab itself or the egg noodles that serve as the bed. So deliciously garlicky. Just make sure you use plenty of Listerine afterwards if it's date night.

Service is reasonably quick and efficient, and the restaurant can get quite packed on weekends with a mixture of Asian and non-Asian customers. Worth making the excursion from elsewhere to check out.

excerpts: \\ Tofu Eggplant - Bean curd, eggplant, bell peppers in soy sauce, served with rice.
tofu eggplant.author: Candice G.
tofu eggplant.review:
Braiiinz. 
Garlic Roasted Dungeness Crab Braiiinz.

Overall the food was good, nothing was a super stand-out and the Dungeness was kind of just aight all things considered, but the garlic noodles served underneath with crab brains mixed in was the absolute highlight and luckily they don't skimp on that. 

I thought the garlic roasted crab itself was just okay- definitely not one of the meatier crab meals I've had this season, and the flavor wasn't as bold as I was hoping, but for the price it wasn't bad at all. 

Our group of 5 got a few dishes all to share and the meal with drinks and minus tip came out to $25 a person. 

Our dishes:

\\ Garlic Roasted Dungeness Crab - Dungeness crab pan fried in browned & garlic with egg noodles. As mentioned the browned & garlic egg noodles with the crab brains were the table favorite, but the crab itself was just alright.

\\ Shrimp Rice Krispies - Shrimp Cakes with water chestnut, sweet rice crust, served with peanut sauce. I'd 100% get these again. 

\\ House Fried Rice - Duck and pineapple stir-fried rice seasoned with scallions and garlic. Not a huge fan. Was a bit too dry and too salty even for me, a person who would sneak into my grandma's car to lick the salt block she kept in the trunk to weigh down the back half of the car as a child.

\\ Imperial Rolls - Pork, mushroom, carrots, lightly fried, served with fresh vegetables & fish sauce. Again, these were just ok. A little too dry for my tastes. 

\\ Tofu Eggplant - Bean curd, eggplant, bell peppers in soy sauce, served with rice. It was just fine but not a standout dish by any means. 

Drink:
\\ Young Coconut - So freaking good. Served in the coconut, so fresh and only $4. Def helped cure my hangover from the night before.

If I could give 3.5 stars I would, but I can't. Based off the dozen or so specialty whole crab dishes I've had for my first crab season living in the bay area, I have to say that while this crab wasn't bad, it so far has been the least impressive, but the price was reasonable, the place is cute, decor is warm, service was fine, and the bathrooms were immaculate and bigger than my apartment.

excerpts: Tofu Eggplant -- Yummy, good with rice (rice texture was great too), and pretty reminiscent of Chinese food in flavor.
tofu eggplant.author: Laura C.
tofu eggplant.review:
I found this place purely by using Yelp and I hope my review convinces you to come too. Le Soleil is a Vietnamese-French fusion restaurant that manages to be classy but not snobby. It's located in a quiet neighborhood in Richmond and the interior atmosphere is quite relaxing and modern as well. 

We arrived around 5:30 or 5:45 and the restaurant was almost empty. More people started coming in after 6:30 but it never felt crowded or noisy. Our waiters were very attentive in refilling our glasses (lemon- and apple-infused water) and changing our plates. But the food was the best part:

Beef Carpaccio -- Appetizer of thinly sliced rare filet mignon. It was my first time having raw beef and the meat melted in my mouth like fresh sashimi. Yum. The side notes of mint, onion, and roasted garlic were satisfying as well.

Green Papaya Salad -- This might have tasted better if it wasn't served right after the Beef Carpaccio, since it had the same mint-onion taste. The green papaya is in shreds and reminded me of turnip salad. It wasn't bad, but I don't think I'd order it again when I return (because I will return).

Quail -- Mmmm. The quail is already cooked when it arrives, but the waiter torches it at the table for good measure and good show. The four of us shared one quail, which was sweet and tender to perfection.

Caramelized Sea Bass -- Perhaps my perfect dish of the night. The texture and taste couldn't have been more satisfying and the brussel sprouts underneath were some of the yummiest I've had.

Dungeness Crab and Garlic Noodles -- I'm not a big fan of garlic noodles but these were delectable. I especially loved the crab, which was drizzled over with the contents of the crab shell (I'm Chinese and my family loves eating that). 

Turmeric Crepe -- I'm not a big fan of the fried taste so this wasn't my favorite dish, but it was also carefully prepared with carrots and greens on the side.

Tofu Eggplant -- Yummy, good with rice (rice texture was great too), and pretty reminiscent of Chinese food in flavor. 

My overall impression of Le Soleil was that each and every detail is carefully attended to. Not only was the food delicately prepared, but the bathroom was very clean and elegantly decorated, and the bill came in a bamboo cup instead of the usual tray or leather book. The meal was a little pricey, at $24 per person, but maybe that's just because we kept ordering more to try the menu. We got what we paid for, though. I'm so glad we live close to San Francisco because we are coming back here for sure.

excerpts: Vegetable curry and tofu eggplant were good.
The fresh vegi rolls were cold and overpriced.
Our server was not very pleasant and seems to be inexperienced.
The head server  was nice.
tofu eggplant.author: G Y.
tofu eggplant.review: Vegetable curry and tofu eggplant were good. The fresh vegi rolls were cold and overpriced. Our server was not very pleasant and seems to be inexperienced. The head server  was nice.

excerpts: Love their pho and tofu eggplant, staff are super friendly and nice, the environment is excellent, and the food is wayyy above average!
Go try it out for sure!
tofu eggplant.author: CaRol L.
tofu eggplant.review: Great place to eat at! My best friend brought me here and it's definitely one of the best places I've tried out in SF! Love their pho and tofu eggplant, staff are super friendly and nice, the environment is excellent, and the food is wayyy above average! Go try it out for sure!

excerpts: There are also vegetarian options like the tofu eggplant and curry veggies.
But, gosh, the garlic-roasted Dungeness crab?
Absolutely delightful, whether the crab itself or the egg noodles that serve as the bed.
So deliciously garlicky.
curry veggies.author: Vincent L.
curry veggies.review:
Quality, authentic Vietnamese fare done in a slightly swankier, more polished setting than, say, hole-in-the-wall restaurants. That having been said, the prices are still quite reasonable.

Traditional dishes like the bo luc lac (shaken beef) and grilled pork are quite dependable. There are also vegetarian options like the tofu eggplant and curry veggies. But, gosh, the garlic-roasted Dungeness crab? Absolutely delightful, whether the crab itself or the egg noodles that serve as the bed. So deliciously garlicky. Just make sure you use plenty of Listerine afterwards if it's date night.

Service is reasonably quick and efficient, and the restaurant can get quite packed on weekends with a mixture of Asian and non-Asian customers. Worth making the excursion from elsewhere to check out.

excerpts: We ordered Beef Carpaccio as appetizer and two entrees Lamb Chops and Curry Veggies.
Food is okay.
With that price, you can go to a quite decent place with larger portion.
Curry veggies are pretty tasty.
curry veggies.author: Carrie Z.
curry veggies.review: The place is not that impressive. We ordered Beef Carpaccio as appetizer and two entrees Lamb Chops and Curry Veggies. Food is okay. With that price, you can go to a quite decent place with larger portion. Curry veggies are pretty tasty.

excerpts: The garlic noodles are awesome, as is the rice porridge, curry veggies and eggplant.
curry veggies.author: S M.
curry veggies.review:
Wow- really really good food.

The garlic noodles are awesome, as is the rice porridge, curry veggies and eggplant.

I've walked by it 100 times and have only recently discovered how good it is.  Prices are decent portions are big and I'll definitely be back.

excerpts: All the dishes were great, especially the eggplant, curry veggies, beef, and the sea bass was perfect, too.
Service was excellent.
The owner was so gracious.
curry veggies.author: Helen L.
curry veggies.review: The light is dim like you are transformed into a different world.  We had 10 people all together and it was great to have so many because we got to try so many dishes.  The restaurant made us a personal appetizer with Vietnamese rolls, duck salad, and crunchy shrimp balls.  Can't ask for a perfect appetizer dish.  Great presentation.  Ask 10 people and go over there, quick!  All the dishes were great, especially the eggplant, curry veggies, beef, and the sea bass was perfect, too. Service was excellent.  The owner was so gracious.

excerpts: We also had the turmeric crepe and the curry veggies, both of which were excellent.
curry veggies.author: Suhl C.
curry veggies.review: I returned to Le Soleil after a long absence.  Prior to the remodel, the food had gone downhilll, and I stopped going.  But curiosity got the better of me so I returned last week for dinner and was pleasantly surprised that both the service and the food was very good.  The shaking beef was to die for, and the lotus root salad was tantalizing.  We also had the turmeric crepe and the curry veggies, both of which were excellent.  I will definitely go back for the garlic roasted dungeness crab, the garlic noodles and the caramelized sea bass.  Yummy!

excerpts: i ordered the tofu claypot ($12) which was a hot pot of fresh and fried tofu, mixed with assorted mushrooms, onions, and a bit of thai chili.
for a cool day, this was the perfect dish to order to satisfy my stomach.
i wasn't a fan of the fried tofu, but i loved the slightly silken texture of the fresh tofu and mushrooms.
tofu claypot.author: Ellen L.
tofu claypot.review:
very nice restaurant for a group setting!  my friends and i, a party of 12, needed a place for a casual lunch, and one of the gals suggested this restaurant in the heart of inner richmond.  this was a GOOD choice b/c we were able to reserve ahead of time and they had a larger, corner table in the back which was perfect for our group, which included 4 babies/toddlers.

we arrived on a sunday afternoon, around 14.00, and the restaurant was fairly full, but not so full that we had a delay in service.  they had many lunch specials, as well as items to order a la carte.

hubby and i ordered the vegetarian spring rolls ($7) to share...these were rolls of mushroom, cabbage, carrot, celery wrapped inside thin rice paper, cut into 8 bite size pieces.  they came with a small side of sweet soy sauce which made for a tasty appetizer, and great start to our meal.

hubby ordered the lemongrass beef special ($13), which came with bbq beef, pickled carrot, mint, bean sprouts, lettuce and chili over a bed of vermicelli noodles.  he thought this was a tasty lunch plate, with great flavors, but he wasn't quite full after finishing his meal.

i ordered the tofu claypot ($12) which was a hot pot of fresh and fried tofu, mixed with assorted mushrooms, onions, and a bit of thai chili.  for a cool day, this was the perfect dish to order to satisfy my stomach.  i wasn't a fan of the fried tofu, but i loved the slightly silken texture of the fresh tofu and mushrooms.  the broth was amazing, not too salty, with a great blend of asian herbs.

service was quite prompt as we didn't have to wait long to order or have food prepared or receive the bill.  our water glasses were filled without us asking.

there was a single women's restroom, and single men's room in the rear, so i actually had to wait a bit, but it wasn't too bad...least the restrooms were kept clean!

parking was a bit of a challenge, esp since there was a farmer's market right outside the restaurant on sunday, but we lucked out and found something about 3 blocks away.

pretty good restaurant with delicious food and reasonable prices, esp for san francisco!

excerpts: The biggest con of the night was the laksa.
There wasn't anything remotely amazing about it to make it $33.
There were only four piece of shrimp, a couple pieces of fishes, mediocre sized tofu, and a bunch of baby octopus fillers.
laksa.author: Timothy C.
laksa.review:
I guess I found my new go to spot for some vietnamese/french influenced eats. I was surprised it was not busy at all on a Friday at 7:20. We were promptly seated as soon as we entered the restaurant. 

As a started, we got soft shell blue crab. It's very rare for us to find any blue crab dish in sf so we got it as soon as we saw it. This was good but the lemon sauce that came with it did not go well with the sweet flavors of the blue crab.

The highlight of the night were the shaken beef and the macadamian crusted lamb chops. The shaken beef was tender and juicy with the right hint of spices. The lamb chop was perfect seared on the edges and when we cut into it, it had the perfect hint of pink. The garlic noodles here were cooked to perfection. It was soft and slippery and was in a generous serving size. 

The biggest con of the night was the laksa. There wasn't anything remotely amazing about it to make it $33. There were only four piece of shrimp, a couple pieces of fishes, mediocre sized tofu, and a bunch of baby octopus fillers. I can't even comprehend how this dish added up to $33.

Service was quick and friendly which was a plus. We got our food in a timely matter and the waiter kept making sure our water was filled.

excerpts: I definitely recommend this place for their Shaken beef, Lamb legs and Laksa.
They have the normal higher end Vietnamese food options like Crab, Garlic noodles etc.
I really wouldn't classify this place to just be Vietnamese because in terms of flavor there is a twist.
Also, how can you call Laksa as a Vietnamese dish?!
Lol it definitely is a cushion restaurant and worth giving a shot to dine in.
The chef is also nice and goes around the floor and greet customers.
Crab and Garlic Noodle might not be the best to try here
but it's still ok
but definitely not Thanh Long or Crustaeseahn level.
laksa.author: Jan R.
laksa.review: Hidden gem in the inner Richmond area of San Francisco. I definitely recommend this place for their Shaken beef, Lamb legs and Laksa. They have the normal higher end Vietnamese food options like Crab, Garlic noodles etc. I really wouldn't classify this place to just be Vietnamese because in terms of flavor there is a twist. Also, how can you call Laksa as a Vietnamese dish?! Lol it definitely is a cushion restaurant and worth giving a shot to dine in. The chef is also nice and goes around the floor and greet customers. Crab and Garlic Noodle might not be the best to try here but it's still ok but definitely not Thanh Long or Crustaeseahn level.

excerpts: We ordered: lollipop chicken, quail, laksa,  imperial roll and spicy chicken coconut soup.
The lollipop chicken had a tender juicy inside and the outside was crispy.
The quail had a sweet taste and was flambeed baked on your table.
The laksa had two jumbo shrimp with deep fried silky soft tofu, I loved the exceptional spicy flavor.
The imperial roll does not have your ordinary egg roll wrapping, this restaurant uses rice paper for the wrapping.
There was a lot of food on the menu that I wanted to try, such as dungeon crab with garlic noodle and sea bass.
The ambience is very comfortable and relaxing, and I would definitely come again when I am in town.
laksa.author: Loretta L.
laksa.review: I was in town visiting SF I ran in to a hidden Asian Fusion restaurant. I was stunned by the taste of the food. We ordered: lollipop chicken, quail, laksa,  imperial roll and spicy chicken coconut soup. The lollipop chicken had a tender juicy inside and the outside was crispy. The quail had a sweet taste and was flambeed baked on your table. The laksa had two jumbo shrimp with deep fried silky soft tofu, I loved the exceptional spicy flavor. The imperial roll does not have your ordinary egg roll wrapping, this restaurant uses rice paper for the wrapping. There was a lot of food on the menu that I wanted to try, such as dungeon crab with garlic noodle and sea bass. The ambience is very comfortable and relaxing, and I would definitely come again when I am in town.

excerpts: We had Laksa Noodle Soup, Chicken Noodle Soup & Traditional Noodle Soup and all were delicious.
We all agreed we will come back.
laksa.author: Kevin K.
laksa.review: We had Laksa Noodle Soup, Chicken Noodle Soup & Traditional Noodle Soup and all were delicious.  We all agreed we will come back.

excerpts: For your main course, make sure to get the shaken beef or grilled pork along with garlic noodles w/ tiger prawns (not on the menu).
tiger prawns.author: Kevin H.
tiger prawns.review:
I have to be honest... I'm a bit conflicted about writing this review. Le Soleil is just a five minute walk from our house, and while it's getting harder and harder to get a table in this city without a reservation, we're usually able to walk right in. I have probably been here ten times, and I find it to be a great experience every time. The reason I'm conflicted about writing this review is that I want to praise this place... but I don't want the secret to get out! I like my minimal wait times for delicious food!

I have never had a dish here that isn't good. The wait staff is super friendly, and everything has such a unique flavor that I haven't really seen replicated at other similar restaurants in the bay area. There are lots of good cheap Asian places in the city, and this place isn't cheap... but it's also not super expensive. Dishes are in the $12 to $18 range. They have so many good dishes - I recommend coming here with a group of four and doing family style. With four people, you'll likely get a table pretty quickly, and you'll be able to share a lot of things.

If it's your first visit to the restaurant and you have four people, I would recommend starting with the imperial rolls and shrimp papaya salad. The rolls are fried, but you wrap them in lettuce and dip them in some sauce. The salad is super refreshing. For your main course, make sure to get the shaken beef or grilled pork along with garlic noodles w/ tiger prawns (not on the menu). Then pick something else that sounds good, and that should be a good meal.

There are some places that are good neighborhood spots, and then there are some that you'll go across town for. I think Le Soleil really is pushing into the latter territory.

excerpts: We didn't and was surprised that we just paid $39 for a few tiger prawns and some sticky fried rice you can get at dim sum.
They also crossed out the 10% or 15% tip calculation on the bill, and highlighted the 18% one.
That just felt tricky!
tiger prawns.author: Eleventy S.
tiger prawns.review: Food was decent but definitely felt overpriced. This came even more true when we realized they charged us $10 extra to SUBSTITUTE garlic noodles with sticky fried rice. We asked if it was possible beforehand, but they never told us there was an extra charge. They assumed we already knew since sticky rice was not on the menu. We didn't and was surprised that we just paid $39 for a few tiger prawns and some sticky fried rice you can get at dim sum. They also crossed out the 10% or 15% tip calculation on the bill, and highlighted the 18% one. That just felt tricky!

excerpts: I ordered a special dish that was tiger prawns on top of garlic noddle.
I'm sorry but any shrimp and a noodle isn't worth $30.
tiger prawns.author: Samuel L.
tiger prawns.review: The food is good. But it's very overpriced. I ordered a special dish that was tiger prawns on top of garlic noddle. I'm sorry but any shrimp and a noodle isn't worth $30.

excerpts: No tiger prawns.
No pepper.
Just Salt.
We
*did* ask the waiter if this was the correct dish his reply was
"Yes this is how the Vietnamese style of cooking is".
I almost laughed because....
That doesn't make sense as my Vietnamese girl agreed was not true.
tiger prawns.author: So L.
tiger prawns.review:
I don't know if this place was better before given the large number of high ratings.   I can only tell you that it was pretty bad when I and my girlfriend went there today.

1)  The rice was dried and hard by any Asian restaurant standards
2)  We ordered Egg Drop Soup.  It was over saturated with some form of corn starch making it basically slimey and not soupy at all.  It basically tasted poor.
3)  We ordered "Salt & Black Pepper Tiger Prawn" and you know what?  It was basically a super duper salty typical stir fry shrimp with onions and no pepper.  

No tiger prawns.  No pepper.  Just Salt.   We *did* ask the waiter if this was the correct dish his reply was "Yes this is how the Vietnamese style of cooking is".   I almost laughed because.... That doesn't make sense as my Vietnamese girl agreed was not true.  It was just a typical cheap Chinese stir fry dish done poorly with WAY WAY too much salt.

Maybe they were better before but I have to say avoid this place for now.

excerpts: would like to try the mango salad, cripsed garlic & black pepper calamari, clay pot garlic prawns, indochinese style salt & black pepper tiger prawns, wok seared sea scallops w/chives & mangoes.
tiger prawns.author: Cindi N.
tiger prawns.review:
4 stars for the food alone. but they've lost stars on service (not friendly) & it always seems cold in here.  our usual:

lunch:  great bbq beef & shrimps with rice noodles (very tastee)

dinner:  
starters:crisped turmeric scented rice flour crepe (light, refreshing with all the fixins -- mint, basil, lettuce, cucumber, carrots or chicken roll 

entree:  beef "look luck"/shaking beef -- the best i've had so far
lemongrass stir-fried chicken
garlic noodles (a bit oily, but i like the flavor)
pan fried thick rice noodles w/prawns & chicken (hub loves this one)
w/ jasmine rice of course

beverages:
guayabano shake (yummee -- don't know if they still serve this)

looks like they've changed some of their menu items  & they've changed/extended the names of some of their items, giving 'em longer names with more descriptive words -- would like to try the mango salad, cripsed garlic & black pepper calamari, clay pot garlic prawns, indochinese style salt & black pepper tiger prawns, wok seared sea scallops w/chives & mangoes.

parking sucks especially in the evenings.

excerpts: Garlic roasted Dungeness crab, whole (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Hb0KDx8ghfUY8J5WzizUmw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) -
Served with garlic noodles, this crab was a solid dish.
The flavors weren't particularly distinct
but you can't beat eating fresh crab when in season.
garlic roasted dungeness crab.author: Mike C.
garlic roasted dungeness crab.review:
The beauty of San Francisco is the variety of cuisines available in a 7 x 7 mile radius.  Not only merely by countries or nations, you can find various regional cooking styles whether north, south, east, or west.  With Vietnamese cuisine, the south and north areas specialize in different signature dishes.

My friends who hosted this meal picked this neighborhood gem for a recent weeknight supper.  Being my first time, I deferred to them in composing our meal.  The dining room was about half full as we were seated at a wall table on the left.  Our party of four fit comfortably here but, after our order was placed, the table seemed small given the food that was to come.

Here's what we shared family style:

Appetizers
1.  Green papaya shrimp salad (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=W3bk1ovEVEhuuM2mhAb6ig&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Refreshing and clean, this was a perfect palate opener.  Love the tangy and sweet fish sauce dressing.

2.  Imperial rolls (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=0mLUIvtX3JTJsH8VICstmg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Always appreciate chefs who stay true to the cuisine, using the proper wrapper (not Chinese spring roll) to make this.  Always a table favorite.

3.  Crispy calamari (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=E1hfdF_pLCiOBeOfVhyXoA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - A non conventional take on fried calamari as this is seasoned with Thai chili sauce and other herbs.  Nice flavor contrast to the first two apps.

Mains
4.  Curry short ribs (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=8k-5WXGICzItTzseiSE3Tg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Tender and boneless, these were easy to eat and paired well with either the garlic noodles or the claypot rice.  The sauce was rich but note overly so.

5.  Garlic roasted Dungeness crab, whole (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Hb0KDx8ghfUY8J5WzizUmw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Served with garlic noodles, this crab was a solid dish.  The flavors weren't particularly distinct but you can't beat eating fresh crab when in season.  Be ready to lick those fingers.

6.  Caramelized sea bass (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fl0s19_lcgnZksbPO0RhDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Not my favorite but another decent dish.  Don't get me wrong, the fish was fine and paired well with the broccoli but it didn't particularly wow me.

7.  Claypot rice (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=cTbzYy1pdlt9zGrHMaTM3A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - There is certainly no shortage of ingredients in this dish as shown in the picture.  Just wished the rice was a tad more crispy for that clay pot effect.

By the time we finished our meal, the dining room was just about full, seemingly with mostly neighborhood locals.  We asked our waiter to pack the leftovers and, after our gracious hosts paid the bill, tried to walk off dinner along Clement Street.

The food ranks four plus with an extra half star for the efficient service (rounding up to five).

excerpts: Garlic Roasted Dungeness crab (half crab)
Dungeness crab pan fried in browned butter and garlic with egg noodles.
The essence of the crab developed the flavors so well coupled with the delicious noodles that were smothered in browned garlic & butter.
I actually quite liked this plate.
It came with the crab cracker which was great because I already broke my tooth once biting onto a crab, it aint happenin again.
garlic roasted dungeness crab.author: Chena N.
garlic roasted dungeness crab.review:
As I was driving to Le Solei, I joked with my very traditional mother (the one who refuses to eat anything except Vietnamese food) over the phone and told her I was going to eat Vietnamese food made by a European guy. She flipped. "WHY... would you do that? It doesn't even sound good already. You should only eat Vietnamese food made by Vietnamese people" HELLA JUDGING OR WHAT MAMA N. I told her not to be so judgmental because fusion food can be pretty good sometimes. AND IT IS DEFINITELY GOOD! BTW, the chefs were not European. 

Le Solei brings in a modern angle of Vietnamese cuisine paired with French influences. Loved the décor as it consisted of intricate things like the ABACUS on their wall... WHAT? Ahah I thought it was super clever. 

Garlic Roasted Dungeness crab (half crab) $25: Dungeness crab pan fried in browned butter and garlic with egg noodles. The essence of the crab developed the flavors so well coupled with the delicious noodles that were smothered in browned garlic & butter. I actually quite liked this plate. It came with the crab cracker which was great because I already broke my tooth once biting onto a crab, it aint happenin again. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=c7UIg8hi2DEABVpkFnM09A#sZwYlLrELTJTm5TCQkxGjw

Luc Lac "Shaken Beef" $16:  Wok tossed flank steak over rice (more like over a lettuce and a bowl of rice on the side... BUT...)  served with lemon pepper butter sauce. LEMME TELL YA... this beef was tender like tender could ever be. Like the cow had a full on body massage and acupuncture or something before it became my food. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=c7UIg8hi2DEABVpkFnM09A#c7UIg8hi2DEABVpkFnM09A
