Fresh Spring Rolls $7: got the pork and shrimp one wrapped with vermicelli and rice paper served with peanut sauce and like some sriracha sauce in the middle? Damn, I died because I cannot handle any type of sauce. But the spring rolls itself were just ok.... not super authentic and not very flavorful as the ones I am used to. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=c7UIg8hi2DEABVpkFnM09A#Y3aSw8ymGAopZ2xPQ-PWeA
 
All in all, as everyone mentioned, and upscale Vietnamese restaurant with some French influences. A bit pricey, but still affordable.

excerpts: Garlic Roasted Dungeness Crab Braiiinz.

Our dishes:

\\ Garlic Roasted Dungeness Crab - Dungeness crab pan fried in browned & garlic with egg noodles.
garlic roasted dungeness crab.author: Candice G.
garlic roasted dungeness crab.review:
Braiiinz. 
Garlic Roasted Dungeness Crab Braiiinz.

Overall the food was good, nothing was a super stand-out and the Dungeness was kind of just aight all things considered, but the garlic noodles served underneath with crab brains mixed in was the absolute highlight and luckily they don't skimp on that. 

I thought the garlic roasted crab itself was just okay- definitely not one of the meatier crab meals I've had this season, and the flavor wasn't as bold as I was hoping, but for the price it wasn't bad at all. 

Our group of 5 got a few dishes all to share and the meal with drinks and minus tip came out to $25 a person. 

Our dishes:

\\ Garlic Roasted Dungeness Crab - Dungeness crab pan fried in browned & garlic with egg noodles. As mentioned the browned & garlic egg noodles with the crab brains were the table favorite, but the crab itself was just alright.

\\ Shrimp Rice Krispies - Shrimp Cakes with water chestnut, sweet rice crust, served with peanut sauce. I'd 100% get these again. 

\\ House Fried Rice - Duck and pineapple stir-fried rice seasoned with scallions and garlic. Not a huge fan. Was a bit too dry and too salty even for me, a person who would sneak into my grandma's car to lick the salt block she kept in the trunk to weigh down the back half of the car as a child.

\\ Imperial Rolls - Pork, mushroom, carrots, lightly fried, served with fresh vegetables & fish sauce. Again, these were just ok. A little too dry for my tastes. 

\\ Tofu Eggplant - Bean curd, eggplant, bell peppers in soy sauce, served with rice. It was just fine but not a standout dish by any means. 

Drink:
\\ Young Coconut - So freaking good. Served in the coconut, so fresh and only $4. Def helped cure my hangover from the night before.

If I could give 3.5 stars I would, but I can't. Based off the dozen or so specialty whole crab dishes I've had for my first crab season living in the bay area, I have to say that while this crab wasn't bad, it so far has been the least impressive, but the price was reasonable, the place is cute, decor is warm, service was fine, and the bathrooms were immaculate and bigger than my apartment.

excerpts: and I just had dinner there, and we were treated graciously by the staff, and had their imperial rolls as an appetizer followed by garlic roasted dungeness crab, and five spice chicken.
All were to die for.
The staff accommodated our request to shell the crab; it was stellar!
garlic roasted dungeness crab.author: Eileen W.
garlic roasted dungeness crab.review:
The food and hospitality at Le Soleil makes my trip from Mountain View to San Francisco worth it!  My best friend and I just had dinner there, and we were treated graciously by the staff, and had their imperial rolls as an appetizer followed by garlic roasted dungeness crab, and five spice chicken.  All were to die for.  The staff accommodated our request to shell the crab; it was stellar!  I've previously had their caramelized sea bass, and that is also superb.  

Le Soleil is a destination restaurant that's an asset to the Richmond neighborhood.  Can't wait till my next visit.

excerpts: I will definitely go back for the garlic roasted dungeness crab, the garlic noodles and the caramelized sea bass.
Yummy!
garlic roasted dungeness crab.author: Suhl C.
garlic roasted dungeness crab.review: I returned to Le Soleil after a long absence.  Prior to the remodel, the food had gone downhilll, and I stopped going.  But curiosity got the better of me so I returned last week for dinner and was pleasantly surprised that both the service and the food was very good.  The shaking beef was to die for, and the lotus root salad was tantalizing.  We also had the turmeric crepe and the curry veggies, both of which were excellent.  I will definitely go back for the garlic roasted dungeness crab, the garlic noodles and the caramelized sea bass.  Yummy!

excerpts: I wanted to try another one of their signature dish very soon, so on a lazy Friday night a week ago, I went back to Le Soleil to try their garlic roasted dungeness crab that chef Dennis recommended.
I did a yelp check-in and got a complimentary spring roll which was fresh and delicious.
I ordered half a crab pan fried in browned butter & garlic served over garlic egg noodles.
There were big pieces of crab claws, legs and meaty pieces all perfectly roasted and oozing with a heavenly finger-licking sauce.
I ate with gusto, but the order was large for one person.
I also got a free light dessert of warm sweet tapioca and cream corn with coconut milk, which was also delicious.
The doggie bag of crab & garlic noodles that I took home was as good as the night before.
I was surprised that the egg noodle was still firm and chewy.
garlic roasted dungeness crab.author: J L.
garlic roasted dungeness crab.review:
Since my first visit to Le Soleil a couple of weeks ago, this little gem of a restaurant has quickly become my favorite go-to place for a satisfyig meal.  On my first visit I had their signature wok-tossed Luc Lac "Shaken Beef" which was tender, juicy and cooked to perfection. The lemon pepper dipping sauce that came with the dish added just the right amount of "tang" to the dish that I wanted to savor every morsel.

I wanted to try another one of their signature dish very soon, so on a lazy Friday night a week ago, I went back to Le Soleil to try their garlic roasted dungeness crab that chef Dennis recommended.  I did a yelp check-in and got a complimentary spring roll which was fresh and delicious.  I ordered half a crab pan fried in browned butter & garlic served over garlic egg noodles. There were big pieces of crab claws, legs and meaty pieces all perfectly roasted and oozing with a heavenly finger-licking sauce. I ate with gusto, but the order was large for one person. I also got a free light dessert of warm sweet tapioca and cream corn with coconut milk, which was also delicious.  The doggie bag of crab & garlic noodles that I took home was as good as the night before.  I was surprised that the egg noodle was still firm and chewy. The chef said it is their own special brand served only at their own restaurants.

I cannot decide which of the two dishes I liked more: the shaken beef or the garlic roasted crab?  When in doubt, try them both!

excerpts: Lemongrass beef lunch special is excellent, incredibly tender.
Grilled pork is wonderfully smoky with read barbecue smoky flavor - the real thing.
Appetizers are all creative with playful texture.
Soups have unusually good flavors as well as texture.
Vietnamese coffee, both iced and hot are made from a custom blend.
Salads are balanced and well done.
If you are new to Vietnamese food, then this place will make you fall in love with it.
If you have only enjoyed banh mi and summer rolls, this place will introduce you to more.
I look forward to tasting more creations of this dynamic restaurant's chef and owner.
Dont come here if you are looking for cheap fast food - in fact, please go elsewhere.
lemongrass beef lunch special.author: Nan L.
lemongrass beef lunch special.review:
It is a rare SF restaurant where the service is this good and the servers are as knowledgeable as the kitchen staff. The attention to patrons here isn't just good, the service is comparable to cities outside of SF. The bathroom is stylish, large, and extremely clean. These factors alone put the restaurant in very good company. 
I've been here about four times for lunch with a friend. The menu is a relief - not too long. The kitchens focus is quality not quantity. The food gives you the impression that they are proud of what they create.
Lemongrass beef lunch special is excellent, incredibly tender. Grilled pork is wonderfully smoky with read barbecue smoky flavor - the real thing.
Appetizers are all creative with playful texture. Soups have unusually good flavors as well as texture.
Vietnamese coffee, both iced and hot are made from a custom blend. Salads are balanced and well done.
If you are new to Vietnamese food, then this place will make you fall in love with it. If you have only enjoyed banh mi and summer rolls, this place will introduce you to more.
I look forward to tasting more creations of this dynamic restaurant's chef and owner.
Dont come here if you are looking for cheap fast food - in fact, please go elsewhere.

excerpts: I tried the mango sticky rice and one of their soups.
I was disappointed when we ordered their fried chicken and we found blood on one of their pieces.
We told our waitress and she was really nice about it and apologized
so she brought out a new batch.
The customer service was excellent it was just that chicken incident that made me give them 3 stars other than that it is a great place to dine at.
mango sticky rice.author: Mikayla M.
mango sticky rice.review: My friends and I were craving Vietnamese food so we decided to check out this place.  I tried the mango sticky rice and one of their soups.  I was disappointed when we ordered their fried chicken and we found blood on one of their pieces.  We told our waitress and she was really nice about it and apologized so she brought out a new batch.  The customer service was excellent it was just that chicken incident that made me give them 3 stars other than that it is a great place to dine at.

excerpts: Mango Sticky Rice 5.5 (fresh mangoes with sweet black sticky rice topped with warm coconut cream) -
This was definitely unique.
mango sticky rice.author: Sarah C.
mango sticky rice.review:
My uncle took me here for dinner yesterday. When he picked me up he mentioned something about Vietnamese food. Sure why not. Showed up and it was totally not what I expected. Modern decor with dim lighting and spacious design. My uncle knew the owner and just let her decide what to make for us. 

Quail 7 (flamed in rum and comes with lemon citrus dipping sauce) - This is entertaining and delicious. They light the quail in front of you and let the flames add the crunch to the skin. It was pretty good. 

Lotus Root Salad 9 (protein, lotus root, carrots, shallots, basil, cucumber, and fresh fish sauce) - Usually comes with beef, but ours came with pork because my uncle is watching his health. This is probably my favorite dish. It was both hearthy and light/refreshing. 

Mango Sticky Rice 5.5 (fresh mangoes with sweet black sticky rice topped with warm coconut cream) - This was definitely unique. I never had a dessert like this before. 

We also had some off the menu stuff but its just a twist of what they have on their menu so same taste. 

Nice spacious and clean restrooms. One men and one women. 

Overall, it was a nice dining experience. Different. I really enjoy Asian fusion. 

Also the workers here are really nice.

excerpts: * Mango Sticky Rice ($5.50) - 3.5
Oh, this reminds me of those wonderful desserts in China!
While all the ingredients were right, the rice wasn't quite sticky enough and was more hard and stale.
mango sticky rice.author: Ziyan C.
mango sticky rice.review:
Had a nice dinner here for a friend's birthday! Took them a while to set up our table even though we had reservations - then again, there were 12 of us, most of our party was late, and many of the groups sitting at the tables that would be ours were taking longer than expected.

Still - enjoyed the food, drinks, and service. All the food had great presentation so there were a lot of "ooh's" and "aah's. Also - the water is fantastic! They have a big pitcher in the bar at the back that has orange + lemon slices in it.

MAJOR BONUS POINTS because I forgot my leftovers, came back 20 minutes later after they'd closed, and the chef was so sweet that he made me an entire new dish! And it was a good one - the Luc Lac beef!

* Shrimp Rice Crispies - 4 stars
(Shrimp cakes & water chestnut filling, sweet rice crust, lightly fried. $7)
I really enjoyed this - think of it as a tightly packed shrimp cube, with crispy outer breading (like that dim sum dish), and a nice peanut-y sauce to dip. 

* Luc Lac "Shaken Beef" - 3.5 stars
(wok tossed flank steak, lemon pepper dipping sauce over rice. $16)
Really great quality beef, though a tiny bit overcooked for my taste. It has a great flavor by itself, but once I added the lemon dipping sauce (actually now that I'm reading this off the menu.. I should have dipped as per its name rather than poured it over all the beef) it became agonizingly tart.

* Macadamia Lamb Chops - 4 stars
(cumin & macadamia crusted lamb chops, with brussels sprouts & japanese sweet yam. $15)
All the ingredients just sounded so intriguing in combination and I don't regret ordering this! The lamb was great, just a hint of rareness in the middle of the chop. The brussels sprouts were a little soggy (I like 'em crispy) but still went well with the sweet yam (the purple type).

* House Fried Rice - 4 stars
(duck & pineapple stir fried rice seasoned with scallions and garlic. $11)
Tried a bite - holy cow this was good! The duck was SUPER tender and the pineapple flavor just enough to give this dish a sweetness without overpowering the savory flavors.

* Mango Sticky Rice ($5.50) - 3.5
Oh, this reminds me of those wonderful desserts in China! While all the ingredients were right, the rice wasn't quite sticky enough and was more hard and stale. It's all about that stickiness!

* Tempuraed Coconut Ice Cream ($4.50) - 4.5 stars
"WOW" was the first word out of everyone's lips who tried this. I've had coconut ice cream before but this one was just shockingly intense, in a great way! The tempura = an added awesome bonus.

excerpts: Lastly, for dessert, we tried the mango sticky rice.
The waiter really undersold this one, so I had my expectations low.
I've personally never had real mango sticky rice, and my friend said that is better.
mango sticky rice.author: Lily N.
mango sticky rice.review:
We tried the soft shelled crab, which was really good and perfectly fried!  Had a nice lemony sauce that nicey complimented this cute dish.

The lotus root salad is also a MUST get!  Since it comes with a fish oil based sauce, it basically reminds me of vietnamese vermicelli, but without the noodle, meats, or chicken.  Great fried onion taste, and it's super healthy with all those root veggies.

Their 5 spice chicken is always veery tender and has a great flavor (I also very much like the fish sauce it comes with).

Their shaken beef is okay.  It's not bad, but I was expecting something more tender.

Lastly, for dessert, we tried the mango sticky rice.  The waiter really undersold this one, so I had my expectations low.  I've personally never had real mango sticky rice, and my friend said that is better.  But from somebody who's never tried it, I thought this fusion version was actually very tasty and interesting.

Overall, a little bit on the fancy side, so their apps and desserts, please expect small.  But their entrees are very generous proportions, and everything is very well-presented.

The overall flavor for every savory item is definitely citrus-- you'll find it in the sauces often.  Even their water is infused with orange and lemon.

excerpts: Had the mango sticky rice for dessert, not great not bad.
mango sticky rice.author: Nami S.
mango sticky rice.review:
It's funny, I've lived a few blocks from this place for the last 4 years but only just tried it for the first time last week. So many restaurants on Clement, so little stomach space.

Anyway. This place was pretty good, a nice ethnic respite from all the ethnic dives on the street. Not that I don't love my ethnic dives, but it's nice to not always have to have  ethnic food under fluorescent lights. The food was very tasty -- we got the caramelized sea bass (a-freaking-MAZING!) and the shaken beef (tasty but standard).

Next time, I might have to get the sea bass again, but will skip the shaken beef. The waitress said that the crab was sick-awesome, so will go for that. Had the mango sticky rice for dessert, not great not bad.

excerpts: The Mango sticky rice is a most try because they use black rice instead of the regular one.
It's so good and their Creme Brulee is also very tasty!
I really love this places!!
mango sticky rice.author: Tammy V.
mango sticky rice.review:
I just simply love this place, the food, the decoration, and the excellent services. I am Vietnamese and my mom makes good Vietnamese food so I have lots of requests for viet food outside. Le Soleil really makes good food and mostly importantly, very reasonable price!!
I love the Imperial Roll,  Fried Chicken, Shaken Beef, Five Spice Chicken, and Garlic Noodles! Their chicken is very very juicy!! 
My friends love their Quail, she was scared when the waiter lights up the quail but when she had her first bite, she was very surprised because it was so delicious. 
The Mango sticky rice is a most try because they use black rice instead of the regular one. It's so good and their Creme Brulee is also very tasty! 
I really love this places!!

excerpts: We ordered the green papaya salad and the quail as the appetizers, the dungeness crab with noodles as the main course, and the mango sticky rice as the dessert.
The salad was decent.
The crab was very not meaty and the noodles that comes with the course is fairly salty for my taste.
And lastly the dessert was okay
, the mango wasn't sour but wasn't sweet either.
And for this quality of the food, I thought the price was fairly expensive.
The crab dish alone was already ~$46.
I much prefer the crab restaurant a few blocks away.
mango sticky rice.author: Johnston C.
mango sticky rice.review: I came here for dinner for two in January.  I thought the service was good, but the food was only so so.  We ordered the green papaya salad and the quail as the appetizers, the dungeness crab with noodles as the main course, and the mango sticky rice as the dessert.  The salad was decent.  The crab was very not meaty and the noodles that comes with the course is fairly salty for my taste.  And lastly the dessert was okay, the mango wasn't sour but wasn't sweet either.  And for this quality of the food, I thought the price was fairly expensive.  The crab dish alone was already ~$46.  I much prefer the crab restaurant a few blocks away.

excerpts: While we like the traditional dishes like the shrimp-pork turmeric crepe and the crab-tomato noodle soup (best we've ever had!), we're also big fans of the fusion dishes like the seabass with brussels sprouts, the macadamia lamb chops, the curry short ribs with garlic bread, and the crab with garlic noodles.
I like how Vietnamese food usually is served with a side of veggies to balance out the meat and carbs.
They also have an extensive drink menu ranging from wines to beer to tea and juice.
macadamia lamb chops.author: Diana B.
macadamia lamb chops.review:
My family and I have been eating here for almost 10 years now so the owners, Chef Dennis and Annie, know us by name and personally serve us. While we like the traditional dishes like the shrimp-pork turmeric crepe and the crab-tomato noodle soup (best we've ever had!), we're also big fans of the fusion dishes like the seabass with brussels sprouts, the macadamia lamb chops, the curry short ribs with garlic bread, and the crab with garlic noodles. I like how Vietnamese food usually is served with a side of veggies to balance out the meat and carbs. They also have an extensive drink menu ranging from wines to beer to tea and juice. I love the fresh coconut juice (and eating the coconut flesh), and discovered a tasty beer from Brazil called Xingu black beer here. 

In addition to their regular menu, Dennis would recommend dishes to us that aren't on the menu, and if we're interested next time, we'd special order the dish the day before so that he can shop for the ingredients. It's wonderful to see a chef that loves his craft and gets excited about cooking for us. We've special ordered crab with steamed egg as well as lobster with sticky rice on special occasions since they're pricier (but worth it in quality). They also welcome our feedback so if you prefer a dish a certain way next time, let them know. 

My parents have lived in Vietnam so we can special order more traditional dishes, too, which he'll try to make with the available ingredients. At lunch today, I asked if he can make the cha ca hanoi fish and the bun cha hanoi grilled pork that I saw in Hanoi, he said sure. I believe that the grilled pork will be added to the regular lunch menu soon. I loved the fish which was lightly fried and served with a plate of veggies, rice paper, and anchovy dipping sauce - he advised us on how to properly wrap and eat the dish. I'm not usually a fan of the anchovy sauce but his version was so good that I finished the sauce.

Just make sure both are working that day and ask for the price of your special order so that there aren't any surprises. I've been there when either Dennis or Annie or both weren't working, and the experience and quality definitely declined so I don't recommend visiting then.

* Macadamia Lamb Chops - 4 stars
(cumin & macadamia crusted lamb chops, with brussels sprouts & japanese sweet yam. $15)
All the ingredients just sounded so intriguing in combination and I don't regret ordering this! The lamb was great, just a hint of rareness in the middle of the chop. The brussels sprouts were a little soggy (I like 'em crispy) but still went well with the sweet yam (the purple type).

* House Fried Rice - 4 stars
(duck & pineapple stir fried rice seasoned with scallions and garlic. $11)
Tried a bite - holy cow this was good! The duck was SUPER tender and the pineapple flavor just enough to give this dish a sweetness without overpowering the savory flavors.

* Mango Sticky Rice ($5.50) - 3.5
Oh, this reminds me of those wonderful desserts in China! While all the ingredients were right, the rice wasn't quite sticky enough and was more hard and stale. It's all about that stickiness!

* Tempuraed Coconut Ice Cream ($4.50) - 4.5 stars
"WOW" was the first word out of everyone's lips who tried this. I've had coconut ice cream before but this one was just shockingly intense, in a great way! The tempura = an added awesome bonus.

excerpts: Luc Lac Shaken Beef (5):
luc lac shaken beef.author: Jeremy L.
luc lac shaken beef.review:
The lobster was amazing!  

Had to special order it in advance cause they go out and purchase a 3 pound lobster just for you!  They said thats the only way chef likes to make it so its not on the menu.  It was amazing though!  Served on a bed of fried rice which was big enough to feed the table.  Everything else that we got on the menu was also amazing!

Lotus Root Salad (5): The appearance of this thing was interesting.  After the first bite though, flavors and textures just exploded!  Just a great combination with bits of beef to contrast the light, sweet, and tangy salad flavors.   

Caramelized Sea Bass (5): As expected, light and melts in your mouth.  Excellent!

Luc Lac Shaken Beef (5): Tender, juicy cubes of beef served with a sort of tangy sauce that contrasts the salty meat well. 

Fried Banana with Coconut Ice Cream (4): Lightly fried bananas with some smooth coconut ice cream.  Simple yet delicious.  

Young Coconut (5): I hesitated on this one.  Just thought it'd be a cut open coconut that you can drink the water from.  Did not expect how amazing this coconut water was!  It was sweeter than expected and had a very refreshing flavor to it.  The coconut meat was also super soft and sweet!  Almost like eating a healthy and natural almond jello.  I'd eat this every day if I could.  

Everything was pretty solid and amazing on this visit.  The food was on point.  The chef even came out and asked us if everything was good and up to our standards (probably cause we special ordered the lobster).  Overall, amazing experience.  Will likely return when we're in the area.  If nothing else than to get that lotus root salad and the young coconut.  Super good!

excerpts: hubby ordered the lemongrass beef special ($13), which came with bbq beef, pickled carrot, mint, bean sprouts, lettuce and chili over a bed of vermicelli noodles.
lemongrass beef.author: Ellen L.
lemongrass beef.review:
very nice restaurant for a group setting!  my friends and i, a party of 12, needed a place for a casual lunch, and one of the gals suggested this restaurant in the heart of inner richmond.  this was a GOOD choice b/c we were able to reserve ahead of time and they had a larger, corner table in the back which was perfect for our group, which included 4 babies/toddlers.

we arrived on a sunday afternoon, around 14.00, and the restaurant was fairly full, but not so full that we had a delay in service.  they had many lunch specials, as well as items to order a la carte.

hubby and i ordered the vegetarian spring rolls ($7) to share...these were rolls of mushroom, cabbage, carrot, celery wrapped inside thin rice paper, cut into 8 bite size pieces.  they came with a small side of sweet soy sauce which made for a tasty appetizer, and great start to our meal.

hubby ordered the lemongrass beef special ($13), which came with bbq beef, pickled carrot, mint, bean sprouts, lettuce and chili over a bed of vermicelli noodles.  he thought this was a tasty lunch plate, with great flavors, but he wasn't quite full after finishing his meal.

i ordered the tofu claypot ($12) which was a hot pot of fresh and fried tofu, mixed with assorted mushrooms, onions, and a bit of thai chili.  for a cool day, this was the perfect dish to order to satisfy my stomach.  i wasn't a fan of the fried tofu, but i loved the slightly silken texture of the fresh tofu and mushrooms.  the broth was amazing, not too salty, with a great blend of asian herbs.

service was quite prompt as we didn't have to wait long to order or have food prepared or receive the bill.  our water glasses were filled without us asking.

there was a single women's restroom, and single men's room in the rear, so i actually had to wait a bit, but it wasn't too bad...least the restrooms were kept clean!

parking was a bit of a challenge, esp since there was a farmer's market right outside the restaurant on sunday, but we lucked out and found something about 3 blocks away.

pretty good restaurant with delicious food and reasonable prices, esp for san francisco!

excerpts: For lunch, the lemongrass beef over vermecilli with imperial roll is one of the best.
lemongrass beef.author: Lawrence L.
lemongrass beef.review: Great Vietnamese Fusion restaurant in the Richmond.  The sea bass is fantastic and  garlic crab and garlic noodle are must order.   For lunch, the lemongrass beef over vermecilli with imperial roll is one of the best.

excerpts: My mom and I got the lemongrass beef with vermicelli noodles, and a plate of fried tofu with spring rolls.
The tofu was perfectly crisp with fried onion on top, and the spring roll was fresh and delicious!
There was also a small side of salad.
The portions were perfect for me.
The lemongrass beef was also tasty, not too fatty.
I think the vermicelli noodles were pretty standard, though the egg rolls were great, crunchy and mouthwatering.
lemongrass beef.author: Vivian L.
lemongrass beef.review:
Came across this place during lunch hours while walking through Clement, and it's a cute little restaurant with an elegant atmosphere. I love Vietnamese food, and their French-Vietnamese fusion is interesting and yummy! 

Before serving your actual order, they bring a small soup/chowder that's tangy and flavorful. Not really sure what was in it, but it tasted like tomatoes and a bit of onion. I really wanted to ask for seconds! My mom and I got the lemongrass beef with vermicelli noodles, and a plate of fried tofu with spring rolls. The tofu was perfectly crisp with fried onion on top, and the spring roll was fresh and delicious! There was also a small side of salad. The portions were perfect for me. The lemongrass beef was also tasty, not too fatty. I think the vermicelli noodles were pretty standard, though the egg rolls were great, crunchy and mouthwatering. 

The price range is a bit expensive for what you get, but I'd say that's a given as it's in SF and the place is pretty nice, clean, and fancy. Customer service is also friendly and quick. Check it out if you're in the area and can't choose where to eat!

excerpts: As recommended, we got the garlic noodles, the chicken/shrimp crepe, and lemongrass beef.
Lemongrass beef came out next
and I was pretty disappointed.
I guess I was expecting too much because for $17, you should be getting a good steal.
However, you get a place of beef and salad that can easily be assembled and eaten at another Viet restaurant for about a third of the price.
lemongrass beef.author: Bryan W.
lemongrass beef.review:
If you are from Orange County California and have been to Little Saigon, then you know of a little place called "Brodard" or "Brodard Chateau." Since there's a lot of influence of French cuisine with Vietnamese cuisine and vice, versa, a lot of fancy Vietnamese restaurants provide a crossover between the two and sell pretty good food for a premium.

That's exactly what Le Soleil was and then some. Le Soleil (what a cool name by the way) is a fancy Vietnamese restaurant that has a lot of fancy crossover Viet/French dishes (like stuff with escargot, crab, etc.). I was craving some Vietnamese food and suggested this restaurant to my friend.

We came around 7pm and luckily found parking right away on Clement St. Fortunately, the Richmond area of SF isn't as bad as Sunset and so it's a bit easier to find parking. There wasn't a line and we were seated right away.

It seems like Le Soleil has pretty steep prices for Viet food that I'd otherwise pay very cheaply for. However, the pictures and reviews were good, so maybe this place really is reputable. As recommended, we got the garlic noodles, the chicken/shrimp crepe, and lemongrass beef.

First, the crepe. This "banh xeo" was BOMB.COM. I've had pretty good Viet crepes that my family has made, but this was is definitely up there as the best. It's $14, but eating just one or two is enough to get you full. What makes this one so good is that the ingredients (shrimp, bean sprouts, chicken) are very fresh and you can taste it. Please get this!

Lemongrass beef came out next and I was pretty disappointed. I guess I was expecting too much because for $17, you should be getting a good steal. However, you get a place of beef and salad that can easily be assembled and eaten at another Viet restaurant for about a third of the price. That said, it was still decent and a fine option if you are looking for a beef item.

Lastly, the garlic noodles. This was one of the highest recommended items and for $10, it's not a bad choice. However, it also tasted like you can make this yourself or buy this for a discount somewhere else. It was still good, and so if you are into garlic noodles and don't want to make them, check this one out. 

tl;dr Le Soleil is a very pricy but fancy Vietnamese/French restaurant. There are many good things about the place but be warned about what you may getting yourself into!

excerpts: Crispy noodles dish was tasty and the lemongrass beef was delicious.
They also have a great coconut soup.
lemongrass beef.author: T K.
lemongrass beef.review:
Really good food and very affordable.    Definitely recommend it. 
Crispy noodles dish was tasty and the lemongrass beef was delicious.   They also have a great coconut soup.

excerpts: Lemongrass beef was delish!
Serive was wonderful.
Will definitely go back!
lemongrass beef.author: Jackie R.
lemongrass beef.review: So great for lunch!  Lemongrass beef was delish! Serive was wonderful. Will definitely go back!

excerpts: Lemongrass Beef served with Chicken Coconut Soup for $10.
lemongrass beef.author: Anita S.
lemongrass beef.review:
This restaurant is right in the heart of Richmond close to all the stores on Clement Street.  Upon entering the restaurant I was shocked to see how beautiful the interior is.  It is elegantly decorated and it has a zen like feel.  I feel comfortable and very relax right away.  

The menu offers many unique dishes.  I was intrigued to see something like Escargot Noodle Soup.  Every dish looks enticing that I want to sample them all.  We ordered a lot for just three people.  We started off with some appetizers.  Shrimp Rice Krispies  and it was served with peanut sauce like many other Vietnamese restaurants but the presentation here is very pretty.  The  Imperial Roll is like no others, it is authentic not a Spring Roll wanna be Imperial Roll. 

We ordered their lunch special  Lemongrass Beef served with Chicken Coconut Soup for $10.  We had the Escargot Noodle Soup, Beef Pho, Roast Duck & Pineapple Fried Rice and Chicken & Shrimp Crispy Noodle.  The food presents well with a touch of fusion look (see photos).  My husband will die for the Imperial Rolls.  I fell in love with the crispy noodle dish.   The food was amazing. It is so good that I'm giving this place 5 stars.   I want to add another star for excellent service if I could give it 6 stars.

excerpts: Ordered the lemongrass beef and five spice chicken and both were fantastic.
Atmosphere is good, modern/clean.
Will definitely be coming back here.
lemongrass beef.author: Yasi N.
lemongrass beef.review: Went here for lunch and really enjoyed it.  They have really great lunch specials as well as a full menu.  Ordered the lemongrass beef and five spice chicken and both were fantastic.  Atmosphere is good, modern/clean.  Will definitely be coming back here.

excerpts: The Imperial Rolls are always crispy and the Lemongrass Beef is high quality.
lemongrass beef.author: Kristyn K.
lemongrass beef.review:
My 5 star reviews may be getting out of hand, but this place is awesome! We go on weekends right when they open because Eats is always so packed and my boyfriend hates breakfast food (what.)  I can't get enough of their Chicken Coconut Soup.  The Imperial Rolls are always crispy and the Lemongrass Beef is high quality.  

Went for dinner with friends and it was delicious.  I had the Half Garlic Roasted Crab and almost died.

is good too!

excerpts: Then I had the lemongrass beef, which was super tender and soft and utterly delicious.
My husband had the asparagus beef (it was beef day
and that was also really good.
Brought the remainders home as there was a lot of food.
It's a little on the splurgy side, or maybe we just ordered too much.
But this is a place where you can eat really delicious vietnamese food.
And the staff was really sweet too.
lemongrass beef.author: Alexandra D.
lemongrass beef.review:
Soooo delicious! 
We came here the other night after looking at cars on Geary and were super hungry. We had imperial rolls, which you can wrap in lettuce and put other goodness inside besides the fried roll. 
Then I had the lemongrass beef, which was super tender and soft and utterly delicious. My husband had the asparagus beef (it was beef day :) and that was also really good. Brought the remainders home as there was a lot of food. 
It's a little on the splurgy side, or maybe we just ordered too much. But this is a place where you can eat really delicious vietnamese food. And the staff was really sweet too.

excerpts: the sampling platter w/ lemongrass beef, imperial rolls, shrimp, lettuce, pickled carrots and this rice paper tortilla was pretty good.
I enjoyed the fact that it was a hands-on type of dish.
We had to assemble it ourselves, and they were lucky that I was in that assembly mood that day.
The curry chicken w/ rice was good.
We all liked it, but for my personal taste, it could've been a bit thicker and heavier tasting.
The chicken was very smooth (the way I like it, so probably chicken breast.
Yes, I'm ABC), and maybe even packaged.
The lemon grass beef w/ rice was just what it was.
lemongrass beef.author: Elaine H.
lemongrass beef.review:
We were debating on where to eat and finally decided to venture into the richmond area and give Burma Superstar a try. They were closed, as I somewhat suspected, since it was about 4pm. We were going to try Clementine, but yes, they were closed until 5 as well. After that, we eventually stumbled into this place. 

It looked like a little cafe on the outside (nothing special), but was nicely decorated on the inside. The service is a little better than your average vietnamese restaurant, but not spectacular either. 

Now for the food-
1. the sampling platter w/ lemongrass beef, imperial rolls, shrimp, lettuce, pickled carrots and this rice paper tortilla was pretty good. I enjoyed the fact that it was a hands-on type of dish. We had to assemble it ourselves, and they were lucky that I was in that assembly mood that day.
2. The curry chicken w/ rice was good. We all liked it, but for my personal taste, it could've been a bit thicker and heavier tasting. The chicken was very smooth (the way I like it, so probably chicken breast. Yes, I'm ABC), and maybe even packaged. 
3. The lemon grass beef w/ rice was just what it was. It was good, but not necessarily better than the ones I've had elsewhere. 

Prices are average and probably a tiny bit higher.

excerpts: Lemongrass beef lunch special is excellent, incredibly tender.
Grilled pork is wonderfully smoky with read barbecue smoky flavor - the real thing.
Appetizers are all creative with playful texture.
Soups have unusually good flavors as well as texture.
Vietnamese coffee, both iced and hot are made from a custom blend.
Salads are balanced and well done.
If you are new to Vietnamese food, then this place will make you fall in love with it.
If you have only enjoyed banh mi and summer rolls, this place will introduce you to more.
I look forward to tasting more creations of this dynamic restaurant's chef and owner.
Dont come here if you are looking for cheap fast food - in fact, please go elsewhere.
lemongrass beef.author: Nan L.
lemongrass beef.review:
It is a rare SF restaurant where the service is this good and the servers are as knowledgeable as the kitchen staff. The attention to patrons here isn't just good, the service is comparable to cities outside of SF. The bathroom is stylish, large, and extremely clean. These factors alone put the restaurant in very good company. 
I've been here about four times for lunch with a friend. The menu is a relief - not too long. The kitchens focus is quality not quantity. The food gives you the impression that they are proud of what they create.
Lemongrass beef lunch special is excellent, incredibly tender. Grilled pork is wonderfully smoky with read barbecue smoky flavor - the real thing.
Appetizers are all creative with playful texture. Soups have unusually good flavors as well as texture.
Vietnamese coffee, both iced and hot are made from a custom blend. Salads are balanced and well done.
If you are new to Vietnamese food, then this place will make you fall in love with it. If you have only enjoyed banh mi and summer rolls, this place will introduce you to more.
I look forward to tasting more creations of this dynamic restaurant's chef and owner.
Dont come here if you are looking for cheap fast food - in fact, please go elsewhere.

excerpts: With a full menu--from garlic noodles to fresh clams to bbq lemongrass beef--this isn't just another pho shop.
Recent  renovations, designer furniture and moderate price increases lead one to wonder if the restaurant has been sold or simply aspires to be  the Slanted Door.
lemongrass beef.author: spot d.
lemongrass beef.review:
Dishes are not novel or inspired but are always delicious at this reliable Vietnamese restaurant on Clement.  With a full menu--from garlic noodles to fresh clams to bbq lemongrass beef--this isn't just another pho shop.   Recent  renovations, designer furniture and moderate price increases lead one to wonder if the restaurant has been sold or simply aspires to be  the Slanted Door.  But for now, thankfully, the food remains solid and unchanged--even if it is now served on rectangular green plates.

Or so I've been told.  Regrettably, San Francisco's arcane and prejudicial health regulations do not allow me to dine in this restaurant.

excerpts: However, a pleasant decor and tablecloths do not make up for the poor dining experience I had last week, when I ordered my usual order of rice noodles with lemongrass beef.
lemongrass beef.author: Melissa G.
lemongrass beef.review:
Downhill alert! I used to love this place, especially since most Vietnamese restaurants down Clement Street leave something to be desired in the cleanliness department. However, a pleasant decor and tablecloths do not make up for the poor dining experience I had last week, when I ordered my usual order of rice noodles with lemongrass beef. Previously, I've really loved Le Soleil's version of this, since they used to serve very fresh ingredients: herbs, lettuce, seasoned, grilled meats and always threw in some pickled onions - yes! 

However, my last meal there, the beef was chewy and gristly but tasted okay, all the way to the very last bite, which unfortunately, was off -- as in BAD, very BAD, leaving a liver taste in my mouth that I had trouble washing out even hours later. I still get the shivers thinking about whether I was permanently poisoned. Thankfully, I did not get sick (I've had that happen before), but I'm not going back. 

You take your chances.

excerpts: I ate the lemongrass beef with vermicelli.
The quality is ok.
You play extra $ for the atmosphere and also the better appearance.
I have been told they just renovation recently.
lemongrass beef.author: Westcott S.
lemongrass beef.review: I ate the lemongrass beef with vermicelli. The quality is ok. You play extra $ for the atmosphere and also the better appearance. I have been told they just renovation recently.

excerpts: I ordered the house fried rice with chicken instead of duck and the chicken it came with was all dark meat, dry, and chewy.
My boyfriend got the five spice chicken which was also all dark meat, very oily, and they charged $2 on top of a $17 entree for rice.
Would not come back.
house fried rice.author: Marlee B.
house fried rice.review: Warm beer, bad service, overpriced and mediocre food. I ordered the house fried rice with chicken instead of duck and the chicken it came with was all dark meat, dry, and chewy. My boyfriend got the five spice chicken which was also all dark meat, very oily, and they charged $2 on top of a $17 entree for rice. Would not come back.

excerpts: This was a nice accompaniment with the house fried rice (with duck).
Finally, the five spice chicken was also satisfying.
It was boneless
but with the skin on (mhmm!).
It was served alongside a fresh slaw of cabbage, onions, carrot, and mint.
The only thing that needed some improvement was the lychee iced tea.
There was hardly a lychee taste in the beverage.
house fried rice.author: James Z.
house fried rice.review:
I went in for an early dinner tonight (around 6 PM) not knowing much about Le Soleil except that I've heard good things about it since I moved to San Francisco. This place is a winner for several reasons: food, ambiance, price, and service.

Since our dinner was rather early, we were the first table in the restaurant. Over the next 90 minutes, Le Soleil filled up with patrons. Clearly this spot is popular among locals. Why wouldn't it be? The food is fantastic. We started off with the imperial rolls (very tasty!) and the chicken & shrimp crepe (also good!). My favorite of the night was the shaken beef. I've ordered this dish at other Vietnamese establishments but I have to say this is the best one I've had. Succulent beef cubes sit over a bed of softened red onions and is served with a lemony sauce. This was a nice accompaniment with the house fried rice (with duck). Finally, the five spice chicken was also satisfying. It was boneless but with the skin on (mhmm!). It was served alongside a fresh slaw of cabbage, onions, carrot, and mint. The only thing that needed some improvement was the lychee iced tea. There was hardly a lychee taste in the beverage. Overall, the flavors were solid and the prices were fair.

Our server was attentive and the others who aided him came by a couple times to check up on us. Lastly, the restaurant is well-kept and is suitable for small or medium-sized groups. Le Soleil is a new favorite on Clement!

excerpts: Next I had the House Fried Rice $13.
It was a nice portion for the price.
The duck wasn't dry but it was a little tasteless.
The fried rice was made perfectly.
Although I'm more used to the flavors of King of Thai's Duck Fried Rice, this is a good choice.
I also tried the Garlic noodles.
It was good, but I feel that it lacked garlic flavor.
It tasted more like a chow mein.
For sure will return in the future.
house fried rice.author: Benita M.
house fried rice.review:
This place was great. I like the decor, food was delicious, and service was excellent.

The Chicken Lollipops $9 are a great starter. There were 5 chicken wings accompanied with sriracha aioli. The wings were cooked and seasoned well. It was soo good and great way to start my meal. Next I had the House Fried Rice $13. It was a nice portion for the price. The duck wasn't dry but it was a little tasteless. The fried rice was made perfectly. Although I'm more used to the flavors of King of Thai's Duck Fried Rice, this is a good choice. I also tried the Garlic noodles. It was good, but I feel that it lacked garlic flavor. It tasted more like a chow mein. For sure will return in the future.

excerpts: \\ House Fried Rice - Duck and pineapple stir-fried rice seasoned with scallions and garlic.
Not a huge fan.
house fried rice.author: Candice G.
house fried rice.review:
Braiiinz. 
Garlic Roasted Dungeness Crab Braiiinz.

Overall the food was good, nothing was a super stand-out and the Dungeness was kind of just aight all things considered, but the garlic noodles served underneath with crab brains mixed in was the absolute highlight and luckily they don't skimp on that. 

I thought the garlic roasted crab itself was just okay- definitely not one of the meatier crab meals I've had this season, and the flavor wasn't as bold as I was hoping, but for the price it wasn't bad at all. 

Our group of 5 got a few dishes all to share and the meal with drinks and minus tip came out to $25 a person. 

Our dishes:

\\ Garlic Roasted Dungeness Crab - Dungeness crab pan fried in browned & garlic with egg noodles. As mentioned the browned & garlic egg noodles with the crab brains were the table favorite, but the crab itself was just alright.

\\ Shrimp Rice Krispies - Shrimp Cakes with water chestnut, sweet rice crust, served with peanut sauce. I'd 100% get these again. 

\\ House Fried Rice - Duck and pineapple stir-fried rice seasoned with scallions and garlic. Not a huge fan. Was a bit too dry and too salty even for me, a person who would sneak into my grandma's car to lick the salt block she kept in the trunk to weigh down the back half of the car as a child.

\\ Imperial Rolls - Pork, mushroom, carrots, lightly fried, served with fresh vegetables & fish sauce. Again, these were just ok. A little too dry for my tastes. 

\\ Tofu Eggplant - Bean curd, eggplant, bell peppers in soy sauce, served with rice. It was just fine but not a standout dish by any means. 

Drink:
\\ Young Coconut - So freaking good. Served in the coconut, so fresh and only $4. Def helped cure my hangover from the night before.

If I could give 3.5 stars I would, but I can't. Based off the dozen or so specialty whole crab dishes I've had for my first crab season living in the bay area, I have to say that while this crab wasn't bad, it so far has been the least impressive, but the price was reasonable, the place is cute, decor is warm, service was fine, and the bathrooms were immaculate and bigger than my apartment.

excerpts:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#RJ1Y4cU5b90Yn8N1M_N5tg)

House Fried Rice - duck and pineapple stirred fried with scallions and garlic.
house fried rice.author: Al L.
house fried rice.review:
Le Soleil calls its cuisine New Vietnamese, a blend of Vietnamese and French styles. Its small, modern décor location on Clement St. is a perfect backdrop to showcase this Vietnamese fusion cuisine. 

The menu is not a multi-page listing, but one page with selections of appetizers, salads, soups and entrees.  After checking out the menu, we ordered:

Imperial Rolls - the rolls were lightly fried and consisted of pork, mushroom, carrots and served with vermicelli, shredded carrots and dichon and lettuce and mint with fish sauce on the side.  Wrap the roll in lettuce with the condiments and drizzle some fish sauce on it for a delicious appetizer. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw)

Green Papaya Shrimp salad - shrimp, green papaya, carrots, mint, tamarind sauce.  A refreshing salad that has hint of sweetness from the tamarind sauce.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#RJ1Y4cU5b90Yn8N1M_N5tg)

House Fried Rice - duck and pineapple stirred fried with scallions and garlic.   Tasty fried rice with the minced duck.  
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#w9aePtdybcTgWGXxePIenQ)

Curry Short Ribs - braised boneless short ribs in yellow curry with potatoes, carrots and lime leaf served with garlic bread.  This was my favorite dish.  The short ribs were probably lightly fried creating a nice light crust to it. The beef was so tender and tasty with the coconut milk curry sauce.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#hY4bqKQNh1odO2yQWZH02Q)

A nice place on Clement for tasty New Vietnamese cuisine in a nice modern décor with friendly service.

excerpts:
* House Fried Rice - 4 stars
(duck & pineapple stir fried rice seasoned with scallions and garlic.
Tried a bite - holy cow this was good!
house fried rice.author: Ziyan C.
house fried rice.review:
Had a nice dinner here for a friend's birthday! Took them a while to set up our table even though we had reservations - then again, there were 12 of us, most of our party was late, and many of the groups sitting at the tables that would be ours were taking longer than expected.

Still - enjoyed the food, drinks, and service. All the food had great presentation so there were a lot of "ooh's" and "aah's. Also - the water is fantastic! They have a big pitcher in the bar at the back that has orange + lemon slices in it.

MAJOR BONUS POINTS because I forgot my leftovers, came back 20 minutes later after they'd closed, and the chef was so sweet that he made me an entire new dish! And it was a good one - the Luc Lac beef!

* Shrimp Rice Crispies - 4 stars
(Shrimp cakes & water chestnut filling, sweet rice crust, lightly fried. $7)
I really enjoyed this - think of it as a tightly packed shrimp cube, with crispy outer breading (like that dim sum dish), and a nice peanut-y sauce to dip. 

* Luc Lac "Shaken Beef" - 3.5 stars
(wok tossed flank steak, lemon pepper dipping sauce over rice. $16)
Really great quality beef, though a tiny bit overcooked for my taste. It has a great flavor by itself, but once I added the lemon dipping sauce (actually now that I'm reading this off the menu.. I should have dipped as per its name rather than poured it over all the beef) it became agonizingly tart.

* Macadamia Lamb Chops - 4 stars
(cumin & macadamia crusted lamb chops, with brussels sprouts & japanese sweet yam. $15)
All the ingredients just sounded so intriguing in combination and I don't regret ordering this! The lamb was great, just a hint of rareness in the middle of the chop. The brussels sprouts were a little soggy (I like 'em crispy) but still went well with the sweet yam (the purple type).

* House Fried Rice - 4 stars
(duck & pineapple stir fried rice seasoned with scallions and garlic. $11)
Tried a bite - holy cow this was good! The duck was SUPER tender and the pineapple flavor just enough to give this dish a sweetness without overpowering the savory flavors.

* Mango Sticky Rice ($5.50) - 3.5
Oh, this reminds me of those wonderful desserts in China! While all the ingredients were right, the rice wasn't quite sticky enough and was more hard and stale. It's all about that stickiness!

* Tempuraed Coconut Ice Cream ($4.50) - 4.5 stars
"WOW" was the first word out of everyone's lips who tried this. I've had coconut ice cream before but this one was just shockingly intense, in a great way! The tempura = an added awesome bonus.

excerpts: House fried rice - fried rice with dick and pineapple.
Can't miss item and it was tasty.
Lots of dishes came with rice
so I'll pass next time.
house fried rice.author: Sammy T.
house fried rice.review:
Wanted to try a new vietnamese fusion and this place came up. We stopped by for a Sunday dinner. Here's what we had:

Shrimp Krispy - fried grounded fillings with burnt rice for that nice crunchy bite. Came with a peanut sauce that overpowers the filling. Wanted to try it based on the description and it was ok. Think I'll try something else next time. 

Papaya salad - typical vietnamese salad. The fish sauce wasn't overpowering, so that was nice. Large portion too, so everyone had at least two servings. Crisp papaya and carrots along with fried onions. Just love he texture of this dish

Sea bass - delicious. Caramelized and the sea bass itself was cooked well. Definitely a good choice. Came with Brussels sprouts and rice. 

Macadamia encrusted Lamb shanks - not a particular fan of lamb in general, but the dish  was good. Came with Brussels sprouts. Again.

Portobello w/asparagus - tossed on a sweet soy sauce , these were a hit. Being a vegetarian isn't half bad. Came with white rice and of course ....Brussels sprouts. 

House fried rice - fried rice with dick and pineapple. Can't miss item and it was tasty. Lots of dishes came with rice so I'll pass next time. No Brussels sprouts with this dish. 

Many vietnamese fusion places out there and it's nice to have found another to add to the rotation. Service was friendly and they kept our water full every time in dipped below halfway. None of this matters unless the food is good so, that's the icing on the cake. I will be back.

excerpts: We also ordered the cube or shaken beef, sea bass, and house fried rice.
Everything came out great and decent portion size.
The sea bass was perfectly crispy, but not over cooked, and the brussels sprouts were DELISH!
It's definitely a nice place to go.
Oh and for drinks, you MUST GET THEIR LYCHEE TEA!!
Seriously, I drank a whole pot to myself...
it's DELICIOUS!
house fried rice.author: Allie D.
house fried rice.review:
Great service, nice and clean restaurant....that's a great starting point for an Asian restaurant!  Now on to the good stuff.....the EATS.

We order the garlic noodles, but with shrimp instead of crabs (i wish we got the crabs).  We also ordered the cube or shaken beef, sea bass, and house fried rice.  Everything came out great and decent portion size.  The sea bass was perfectly crispy, but not over cooked, and the brussels sprouts were DELISH!  It's definitely a nice place to go.  Oh and for drinks, you MUST GET THEIR LYCHEE TEA!!  Seriously, I drank a whole pot to myself...it's DELICIOUS!

excerpts: I got the veggie curry and he got the house fried rice with duck.
He threw up that night and i woke up with a terrible allergic reaction!
I have never been allergic to anything before.
You are warned!!!
house fried rice.author: Adam T.
house fried rice.review: Me and my friend ate here two nights ago. I got the veggie curry and he got the house fried rice with duck. He threw up that night and i woke up with a terrible allergic reaction! I have never been allergic to anything before. You are warned!!!

excerpts: Try the house fried rice w duck and pineapple.
I am picky about my fried rice and this blew my mind.
house fried rice.author: Amelia S.
house fried rice.review: Amazing!! Try the house fried rice w duck and pineapple. I am picky about my fried rice and this blew my mind.

excerpts:
My favorites are:

- Garlic noodle with Crab
- Luc Lac Shaken Beef
- House Fried Rice
- Beef Carpaccio
- Flambeed Quail 
- Imperial and Spring rolls
- Soy glazed Seabass

And don't forget the desserts!
house fried rice.author: Karen L.
house fried rice.review:
Absolutely delicious!  Thinking about their menu now is making me drool. 

My favorites are:

- Garlic noodle with Crab
- Luc Lac Shaken Beef
- House Fried Rice
- Beef Carpaccio
- Flambeed Quail 
- Imperial and Spring rolls
- Soy glazed Seabass

And don't forget the desserts! Fried coconut ice cream, sticky rice with mango...YUM!

excerpts: The Shaking Beef, House Fried Rice, and Curry Prawns were delicious.
I heard this place recently went through a remodel and it shows.
house fried rice.author: Casual C.
house fried rice.review: I came here for dinner with my family last week and was surprised with how attentive the service is at this family run establishment.  The Shaking Beef, House Fried Rice, and Curry Prawns were delicious.  I heard this place recently went through a remodel and it shows.

excerpts: Thumbs up on oxtail soup, eggplant & tofu, and portobello mushroom.
The lamb chops weren't my favorite.
The shaken beef was tender.
oxtail.author: Angelia H.
oxtail.review:
Ambience is nice, service is good. Overall, I felt the appetizers were better tasting than the main dishes. 
The lotus root salad and green papaya salad were good, but tasted similar. I liked the duck rolls, calamari, beef carpaccio, and would have ordered seconds if we didn't have all the other dishes. Lollipop chicken and shrimp krispies were decent for deep fried food lovers. Garlic noodles and crab fried rice were just enough for side dishes. Thumbs up on oxtail soup, eggplant & tofu, and portobello mushroom. The lamb chops weren't my favorite. The shaken beef was tender.

excerpts: Overall I would say def order oxtail stew and sea bass.
I would come back and try their Garlic noodles with half crab ($25 mp today).
oxtail.author: Elaine L.
oxtail.review:
Pretty good food but a pricier than your typical Vietnamese/Asian cuisine. We ordered: 
-chicken pops: pass. Reminded me of non crispy fried chicken 
-soft shell crab appetizer: not bad with the lemon sauce
-duck rolls: tasty. $9 for "8 pieces" but it's really two tightly rolled spring rolls that they cut up into 8 pieces. Value wise you're better off getting something else 
-oxtail stew: yum! I liked this dish with a side of white rice (they have a brown rice option as well) 
-shaking beef: I liked the size of the beef cubes. Standard dish at most viet restaurants and it comes with a salt/lemon/pepper sauce 
-sea bass: this is also a good dish. Cooked perfectly and great flavor. 

Water is orange infused. Ooh you fancy huh. 

Service was great. They brought the dishes out quickly and was very attentive in keeping our water filled. Bathroom was clean. 

Overall I would say def order oxtail stew and sea bass. I would come back and try their Garlic noodles with half crab ($25 mp today).

excerpts: We ordered oxtail stew(off menu), a roasted crab, egg rolls, five spice chicken, garlic noodles, and lots of merlot to help things move along.
Their eggrolls were flavorful as well.
Overall, we were very pleased with the food at Le Soleil.
The waitresses were friendly and one even conversed with me in Vietnamese.
The old items are very reasonably priced for the quality of food and services they provide.
I almost forgot to mention the sea bass -
although tasty, it missed the mark as a Vietnamese dish.
Fried with too much batter, but still moist and tasty.
I would have liked to see caramelized clay pot fish (ca kno to) served at this restaurant, but there are other places I can go for that.
oxtail.author: Duke D.
oxtail.review:
Our group of 16 people went to Le Soleil last week as our Vietnamese Food Safari event in search of the best banh xeo in San Francisco.  Although, a few believed they have found it here, I find it to be very good but can not crown it was the best.  We were pleasantly surprise with other Vietnamese dishes there as well, so much so that my friend and I went back last night to try out more dishes.  

Last week was a treat for us, because Martin Yan of Yan Can Cook was also there with his friends.  Martin was nice enough to introduced Le Soleil's chef and posed for pictures with us. Back to the food - the banh xeo we had was quite good. It was crispy and loaded with bean sprouts and mung beans.  I would have liked it to have more pork and shrimp, but maybe my portion of the crepe missed the goodies inside.  I've always said a good banh xeo is only as good as the Vietnamese fish vinegarette (nuoc mam) it is dipped in.  The nuoc mam was near perfect and tasty.  We ordered two lotus root salads - very good and refreshing. Two shaken beef (bo luc lac) - one dish was very good and the second was perfection!  We ordered oxtail stew(off menu), a roasted crab, egg rolls, five spice chicken, garlic noodles, and lots of merlot to help things move along. Their eggrolls were flavorful as well.  Overall, we were very pleased with the food at Le Soleil. The waitresses were friendly and one even conversed with me in Vietnamese.  The old items are very reasonably priced for the quality of food and services they provide. I almost forgot to mention the sea bass - although tasty, it missed the mark as a Vietnamese dish.  Fried with too much batter, but still moist and tasty. I would have liked to see caramelized clay pot fish (ca kno to) served at this restaurant, but there are other places I can go for that.  Although we did not find the best banh xeo here, we did find many flavorful dishes that will sure to bring us back again and again. 

Enjoy!

Let me know what you think of the dishes serve at this restaurant.  Like any restaurant, there will be good days and bad days. I have a feeling this place has more good days than most.

excerpts: Oxtail stew is not on official menu, but my parents come here often and knew it is sometimes available.
Service is very attentive.
The owner comes out to greet guests.
Did not leave with parched "MSG" after-effects that you get from many Asian restaurants.
It gets busy, but not as packed as B-Star next door.
Very nicely remodeled and nice bathrooms.
oxtail.author: N c.
oxtail.review: Shaken beef, curry prawns are delish!! Oxtail stew is not on official menu, but my parents come here often and knew it is sometimes available. Service is very attentive. The owner comes out to greet guests. Did not leave with parched "MSG" after-effects that you get from many Asian restaurants.  It gets busy, but not as packed as B-Star next door. Very nicely remodeled and nice bathrooms.

excerpts: The bomb: imperial rolls, pho soup, oxtail stew, and much more.
Reasonable prices, friendly, and low-key.
oxtail.author: Sumi Y.
oxtail.review: I like this place a lot when I'm not in the mood for greasy-spoon Vietnamese. The bomb: imperial rolls, pho soup, oxtail stew, and much more. Reasonable prices, friendly, and low-key.

excerpts: Curry short ribs (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=8k-5WXGICzItTzseiSE3Tg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Tender and boneless, these were easy to eat and paired well with either the garlic noodles or the claypot rice.
Claypot rice (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=cTbzYy1pdlt9zGrHMaTM3A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q)
- There is certainly no shortage of ingredients in this dish as shown in the picture.
curry short ribs.author: Mike C.
curry short ribs.review:
The beauty of San Francisco is the variety of cuisines available in a 7 x 7 mile radius.  Not only merely by countries or nations, you can find various regional cooking styles whether north, south, east, or west.  With Vietnamese cuisine, the south and north areas specialize in different signature dishes.

My friends who hosted this meal picked this neighborhood gem for a recent weeknight supper.  Being my first time, I deferred to them in composing our meal.  The dining room was about half full as we were seated at a wall table on the left.  Our party of four fit comfortably here but, after our order was placed, the table seemed small given the food that was to come.

Here's what we shared family style:

Appetizers
1.  Green papaya shrimp salad (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=W3bk1ovEVEhuuM2mhAb6ig&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Refreshing and clean, this was a perfect palate opener.  Love the tangy and sweet fish sauce dressing.

2.  Imperial rolls (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=0mLUIvtX3JTJsH8VICstmg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Always appreciate chefs who stay true to the cuisine, using the proper wrapper (not Chinese spring roll) to make this.  Always a table favorite.

3.  Crispy calamari (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=E1hfdF_pLCiOBeOfVhyXoA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - A non conventional take on fried calamari as this is seasoned with Thai chili sauce and other herbs.  Nice flavor contrast to the first two apps.

Mains
4.  Curry short ribs (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=8k-5WXGICzItTzseiSE3Tg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Tender and boneless, these were easy to eat and paired well with either the garlic noodles or the claypot rice.  The sauce was rich but note overly so.

5.  Garlic roasted Dungeness crab, whole (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Hb0KDx8ghfUY8J5WzizUmw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Served with garlic noodles, this crab was a solid dish.  The flavors weren't particularly distinct but you can't beat eating fresh crab when in season.  Be ready to lick those fingers.

6.  Caramelized sea bass (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fl0s19_lcgnZksbPO0RhDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Not my favorite but another decent dish.  Don't get me wrong, the fish was fine and paired well with the broccoli but it didn't particularly wow me.

7.  Claypot rice (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=cTbzYy1pdlt9zGrHMaTM3A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - There is certainly no shortage of ingredients in this dish as shown in the picture.  Just wished the rice was a tad more crispy for that clay pot effect.

By the time we finished our meal, the dining room was just about full, seemingly with mostly neighborhood locals.  We asked our waiter to pack the leftovers and, after our gracious hosts paid the bill, tried to walk off dinner along Clement Street.

The food ranks four plus with an extra half star for the efficient service (rounding up to five).

excerpts: - curry short ribs: really flavorful curry and the meat was extremely tender.
Waitress suggested that we get the garlic bread to dip the curry in.
It was fine but not necessary.
The combination was kinda interesting
and I think white rice would have been fine.
curry short ribs.author: Lucy Z.
curry short ribs.review:
The whole restaurant was empty except for us... for two hours... on a Wednesday night. Based on the reviews, that was definitely a surprise. Almost felt kinda bad for them :/

We ordered:
- fried rice (with duck!): the duck pieces were small but overall it was a pretty tame dish but generous serving size.
- curry short ribs: really flavorful curry and the meat was extremely tender. Waitress suggested that we get the garlic bread to dip the curry in. It was fine but not necessary. The combination was kinda interesting and I think white rice would have been fine. Serving was also slightly more generous than I expected. 

Overall, definitely not the typical "authentic" Vietnamese place with $10 pho and vermicelli bowls but for the taste and ambiance, I'm a fan. Still kinda surprised at the lack of customers though... almost made me suspicious.

excerpts: Curry short ribs (the meats were very tender and curry was good
and it was good to eat with rice)
There were so good that we almost eat everything that we order except for
the fried rice only had a few bite.
By the time the fried rice came out, we were already full but we took it home.
Good thing that we didnt get the crepe.
We thought we order the crepe but never came and good thing that they never charge for it anyways.
May come back next time
curry short ribs.author: Julie N.
curry short ribs.review:
Came here for my birthday lunch with my family. we don't usually go to a lot of vietnamese restaurants since we always eat vietnamese food at home. But we just wanted to give this place a try. When you read the name of this place, it doesn't sound like its a vietnamese restaurant. When you come inside, its very clean and modern. It wasn't full when we came in for lunch. 

The workers here are nice but there were only Couple workers who work in the customers: 1 who bring out food only while the other person takes your orders. The person who takes your order sometime bring out your food too. So it'll take them a while to get to you to give you your utensils and menus and as well getting your orders especially if they are busy. They would give lunch menu first if you come in for lunch but we also asked for the dinner menu so we can get more option of picking the foods. After we order most of the dishes come after the other. Some come at reasonable time while some took a longer than others

My family ordered so much food like we were ready to eat for dinner. The foods are in smaller portion. Here are the food that we ordered:
1. Garlic noodle with Dungeness crab (never seen crab on garlic noodle before)
2. Vegetarian brown fried rice
3. Catfish clay pot (this dish was really really sweet so you definitely need to eat with white rice)
4. Imperial egg roll
5. Escargot noodle (this one is soup). Thought it was interesting to see escargot in a noodle soup type. Almost the same color as bun rieu
6. Beef capriccio with shrimp chip: although its raw but it has a sweetness flavor to it
7. Papaya salad (thought it was alright)
8. Curry short ribs (the meats were very tender and curry was good and it was good to eat with rice)
There were so good that we almost eat everything that we order except for the fried rice only had a few bite. By the time the fried rice came out, we were already full but we took it home. Good thing that we didnt get the crepe. We thought we order the crepe but never came and good thing that they never charge for it anyways. May come back next time

excerpts: While we like the traditional dishes like the shrimp-pork turmeric crepe and the crab-tomato noodle soup (best we've ever had!), we're also big fans of the fusion dishes like the seabass with brussels sprouts, the macadamia lamb chops, the curry short ribs with garlic bread, and the crab with garlic noodles.
I like how Vietnamese food usually is served with a side of veggies to balance out the meat and carbs.
They also have an extensive drink menu ranging from wines to beer to tea and juice.
curry short ribs.author: Diana B.
curry short ribs.review:
My family and I have been eating here for almost 10 years now so the owners, Chef Dennis and Annie, know us by name and personally serve us. While we like the traditional dishes like the shrimp-pork turmeric crepe and the crab-tomato noodle soup (best we've ever had!), we're also big fans of the fusion dishes like the seabass with brussels sprouts, the macadamia lamb chops, the curry short ribs with garlic bread, and the crab with garlic noodles. I like how Vietnamese food usually is served with a side of veggies to balance out the meat and carbs. They also have an extensive drink menu ranging from wines to beer to tea and juice. I love the fresh coconut juice (and eating the coconut flesh), and discovered a tasty beer from Brazil called Xingu black beer here. 

In addition to their regular menu, Dennis would recommend dishes to us that aren't on the menu, and if we're interested next time, we'd special order the dish the day before so that he can shop for the ingredients. It's wonderful to see a chef that loves his craft and gets excited about cooking for us. We've special ordered crab with steamed egg as well as lobster with sticky rice on special occasions since they're pricier (but worth it in quality). They also welcome our feedback so if you prefer a dish a certain way next time, let them know. 

My parents have lived in Vietnam so we can special order more traditional dishes, too, which he'll try to make with the available ingredients. At lunch today, I asked if he can make the cha ca hanoi fish and the bun cha hanoi grilled pork that I saw in Hanoi, he said sure. I believe that the grilled pork will be added to the regular lunch menu soon. I loved the fish which was lightly fried and served with a plate of veggies, rice paper, and anchovy dipping sauce - he advised us on how to properly wrap and eat the dish. I'm not usually a fan of the anchovy sauce but his version was so good that I finished the sauce.

Just make sure both are working that day and ask for the price of your special order so that there aren't any surprises. I've been there when either Dennis or Annie or both weren't working, and the experience and quality definitely declined so I don't recommend visiting then.

excerpts:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#w9aePtdybcTgWGXxePIenQ)

Curry Short Ribs - braised boneless short ribs in yellow curry with potatoes, carrots and lime leaf served with garlic bread.
curry short ribs.author: Al L.
curry short ribs.review:
Le Soleil calls its cuisine New Vietnamese, a blend of Vietnamese and French styles. Its small, modern décor location on Clement St. is a perfect backdrop to showcase this Vietnamese fusion cuisine. 

The menu is not a multi-page listing, but one page with selections of appetizers, salads, soups and entrees.  After checking out the menu, we ordered:

Imperial Rolls - the rolls were lightly fried and consisted of pork, mushroom, carrots and served with vermicelli, shredded carrots and dichon and lettuce and mint with fish sauce on the side.  Wrap the roll in lettuce with the condiments and drizzle some fish sauce on it for a delicious appetizer. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw)

Green Papaya Shrimp salad - shrimp, green papaya, carrots, mint, tamarind sauce.  A refreshing salad that has hint of sweetness from the tamarind sauce.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#RJ1Y4cU5b90Yn8N1M_N5tg)

House Fried Rice - duck and pineapple stirred fried with scallions and garlic.   Tasty fried rice with the minced duck.  
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#w9aePtdybcTgWGXxePIenQ)

Curry Short Ribs - braised boneless short ribs in yellow curry with potatoes, carrots and lime leaf served with garlic bread.  This was my favorite dish.  The short ribs were probably lightly fried creating a nice light crust to it. The beef was so tender and tasty with the coconut milk curry sauce.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#hY4bqKQNh1odO2yQWZH02Q)

A nice place on Clement for tasty New Vietnamese cuisine in a nice modern décor with friendly service.

excerpts: Highly recommend the curry short ribs.
Why?
I think the short rib was fried a bit with a crunchy texture and with curry is the best.
The fried chicken lollipop is a must try too with a special sauce that comes with.
Bill was very reasonable too for 6 adults.
curry short ribs.author: rod h.
curry short ribs.review:
On a busy Sunday waiting was less than 10 min for party of 6. Decoration and atmosphere was inviting. Clean place and bathroom is well kept too. Customer service was excellent, staff was very patient and accommodating. One of the guy at our table impatiently asked for a bowl twice because the staff forgot. The staff kept her professionalism and patient even though the guy at our table was being annoying and impatient. 

Highly recommend the curry short ribs. Why? I think the short rib was fried a bit with a crunchy texture and with curry is the best. The fried chicken lollipop is a must try too with a special sauce that comes with. Bill was very reasonable too for 6 adults. I think 7 dishes total. 

If you like coffee try the Vietnamese coffee!

excerpts: For dinner, I'll recommend you to get their Curry Short Ribs and Sea Bass.
Curry Short Ribs (4.5/5)
- I always love the flavor of the curry.
I am not a big fan of curry
but i love what they serve there.
It usually comes with 7 pieces of meat, which is so tender and flavorful.
It also comes with garlic bread, but I always change it to rice.
, they accommodate my request very well, they even remember that I always want rice instead of garlic bread for my curry short ribs.
Every time I go there, I always have a pleasant experience and happy tummy.
curry short ribs.author: Ulrica J.
curry short ribs.review:
If somebody asks me where they can get a good food with affordable price, great ambiance and very nice service, I will definitely recommend them to go to Le Soleil.

I always love their foods. For dinner, I'll recommend you to get their Curry Short Ribs and Sea Bass.

1. Curry Short Ribs (4.5/5)
- I always love the flavor of the curry. I am not a big fan of curry but i love what they serve there. It usually comes with 7 pieces of meat, which is so tender and flavorful. It also comes with garlic bread, but I always change it to rice. I prefer to have it that way, but sometimes they also give me both rice and the garlic bread.

2. Sea Bass
- For those who can't eat curry or what to eat something less sinful. I will recommend them to order the seabass, it is served with brussels sprouts and it so tasty as well.

Others:
I always order their calamari, which taste incredibly great. They said they took it away from their menu because it takes long to cook it, but they will serve it if you ask. It might took a while, but it is worth the wait.

Friday specials : be sure to try their hainan chicken rice, I always go there once in a month to eat their hainan chicken rice.

Lunch Special : their claypot also taste really good but it's only served for lunch time. 

Service: the lady who work there, the chef, well everybody are so friendly, they accommodate my request very well, they even remember that I always want rice instead of garlic bread for my curry short ribs. Every time I go there, I always have a pleasant experience and happy tummy.

excerpts: Great place, bit pricey more usual than average (about 18-20 per dish depending on what you get) as the prices rose, but do try the curry short ribs.
Its a weird in a good way mix of crunchy and tenderness.
But try the curry short ribs first
curry short ribs.author: Chris C.
curry short ribs.review:
